choices.text: CCBs are the first line in all patients
Lung transplant is the best treatment if identified early

questions.text: A 44-year-old female who is a known case of scleroderma presented with shortness of breath, especially during exercise. She underwent right heart catheterization, and her mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) was 35 mm Hg. Which of the following is true regarding her condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endothelin antagonists improve symptoms

 

The patient has pulmonary hypertension associated with scleroderma, specifically type 1 pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). The right heart catheterization confirms the diagnosis, which is the gold standard for assessing pulmonary hypertension. In patients with PAH, especially those related to connective tissue diseases like scleroderma, endothelin receptor antagonists (ERAs), such as Bosentan, Ambrisentan, and Macitentan, are commonly used to improve symptoms and enhance the patient's functional status. ERAs work by blocking the effects of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor, thus reducing pulmonary vascular resistance and improving outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CCBs are the first line in all patients: Calcium Channel Blockers (CCBs) are not universally used as first-line treatment in all PAH patients. They are only indicated for patients who have a positive response to vasoreactivity testing. For those without a positive response, other targeted therapies, such as endothelin antagonists, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, or prostacyclin analogs, are more appropriate.

 

Option C. Lung transplant is the best treatment if identified early: Although lung transplant may be an option for severe, refractory cases, it is not considered the best treatment due to the complexity and risks associated with the procedure, especially in PAH patients. It is generally reserved for those who fail medical therapy.

 

Option D. Lifestyle modification: While lifestyle changes can support overall health, they do not directly address the underlying pathophysiology of PAH. Therefore, lifestyle modifications alone are not sufficient as a primary treatment approach for pulmonary hypertension, especially when associated with scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endothelin receptor antagonists are effective in improving symptoms and functional status in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with scleroderma.

choices.text: Add Fluticasone MDI two times a day
Shift to MDI Salmeterol two times a day

questions.text: A 24-year-old male who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented for a routine follow-up. PFT was done earlier—his FEV1 was 70%, which improved to 83% after bronchodilator nebulization. He was already on MDI Albuterol daily. On questioning, it seems like he is being symptomatic for at least 2 times per week and is waking up in the nights due to symptoms at least once per week. On examination, there are scattered rhonchi. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Add Fluticasone MDI two times a day

 

The patient’s symptoms indicate that his asthma is not well-controlled with short-acting beta-agonist (Albuterol) alone. Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS), such as Fluticasone, are essential in asthma management because they address airway inflammation, which is a key component of asthma pathophysiology. Adding an ICS will help reduce symptoms, improve lung function, and prevent exacerbations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shift to MDI Salmeterol two times a day: Salmeterol is a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) that can help control symptoms but does not address the underlying inflammation. LABA should not be used as monotherapy in asthma without an accompanying ICS due to the risk of worsening asthma control.

 

Option C. Add Prednisolone 10mg: Prednisolone is a systemic corticosteroid, which is generally reserved for severe asthma exacerbations or patients who do not respond to standard therapy (steps 5 and 6 of the asthma management algorithm). Long-term use is associated with significant side effects, making it inappropriate for this patient’s current condition.

 

Option D. Continue the current management: Continuing the current management is not appropriate as the patient is symptomatic, indicating inadequate asthma control. Adjusting the treatment plan is necessary to improve his symptoms and prevent nighttime awakenings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled corticosteroids are the cornerstone of asthma management as they effectively reduce airway inflammation, improve symptoms, and prevent exacerbations. They should be added when asthma symptoms are not controlled by a short-acting beta-agonist alone.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiplex PCR    

 

Multiplex PCR is a technique that allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single PCR reaction. This makes it particularly useful for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, such as when diagnosing conditions like diarrhea that can be caused by a variety of pathogens including viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Multiplex PCR uses multiple sets of primers in a single reaction mixture, each specific for a different target, allowing the detection of multiple organisms in one run.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nested PCR: This technique is designed to increase the specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in two successive runs, but it is not intended for simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens. It is primarily used to reduce non-specific binding and enhance detection sensitivity for a specific target.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR: While real-time PCR can quantify DNA or RNA targets and is highly sensitive, it typically amplifies one target per reaction or a few targets in separate reactions rather than multiple agents in a single test.

 

Option C. Conventional PCR: This method involves amplifying a single DNA target per reaction and is not designed to handle multiple targets simultaneously, making it less suitable for identifying multiple causative agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with dysmenorrhea. Laparoscopic finding is as shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

The laparoscopic image shows an ovarian cyst filled with dark brown material, characteristic of a "chocolate cyst" or endometriotic cyst (endometrioma). Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue, which normally lines the uterus, grows outside it, commonly on the ovaries, forming cysts filled with old blood. This is why they appear dark brown, resembling melted chocolate. The key symptom of endometriosis, as seen in this patient, is dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation), which strongly supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts, also known as mature cystic teratomas, contain various tissue types like hair, skin, and fat. They appear heterogeneous on imaging, often with calcifications, unlike the homogeneous blood-filled appearance of an endometriotic cyst.

 

Option C. PID (Pelvic Inflammatory Disease): PID is an infection of the female reproductive organs, often presenting with pelvic pain, fever, and abnormal discharge. It does not typically result in cyst formation like what is seen in the image. PID usually shows inflamed and thickened structures rather than a distinct cystic mass.

 

Option D. Fibroid: Fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus, usually solid and non-cystic in appearance. They do not present with blood-filled cysts on the ovaries as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus, commonly forming chocolate cysts in the ovaries, which present as dark, blood-filled cysts on laparoscopic examination.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option B. Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Option D. Coccidioidomycosis: Coccidioides immitis exists as spherules filled with endospores in tissue, not as budding yeast. It is endemic to the southwestern United States, especially Arizona and California.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text: The given image is the logo for which of the following health programs? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) National Leprosy Eradication Program


The logo shown is for the National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP). The design of the logo holds significant meaning:

 

  • Sun: The sun in the center of the hand symbolizes hope and optimism, reflecting the positive outcomes of leprosy treatment.
  • Lotus Flower: This represents purity and beauty, indicating that there should be no stigma attached to those affected by leprosy.
  • Cured Thumb: The image of the healed thumb symbolizes that leprosy is a 100% curable disease. The thumb indicates that the affected person has been cured and is now a fully integrated member of society.
  • House-Shaped Hand: The hand shaped like a house emphasizes that the cured individual is an integral part of their family and community.

 

These elements collectively reinforce the message of hope, inclusion, and the need to remove stigma associated with leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrated Disease Surveillance Program (logo):

 

 

Option B.  National TB Elimination Program (logo):

 

 

Option D.  National Health Mission (logo):

 

 

Educational Objective:


The National Leprosy Eradication Program logo symbolizes hope, the curability of leprosy, and the inclusion of cured individuals into society, promoting a stigma-free approach towards the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely disease looking at the pattern of inheritance as provided in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

The pedigree in the image shows an inheritance pattern typical of X-linked recessive conditions. In this pattern, affected males inherit the disease from carrier mothers, while females are usually carriers and do not show the disease. All affected individuals are male, and carrier females are represented by circles with a dot. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome follows an X-linked recessive inheritance, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wilson’s disease: This condition is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both males and females are equally affected, and carriers are not seen in the pattern observed here.

 

Option C. Achondroplasia: This condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It would appear in every generation and affect both males and females equally, which is not the case in the presented pedigree.

 

Option D. Leber disease: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy is inherited through maternal (mitochondrial) inheritance. It does not follow an X-linked recessive pattern and affects both sexes through maternal transmission only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked recessive conditions are characterized by affected males and carrier females, as males have only one X chromosome, making them susceptible if the gene is defective.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE")

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

questions.text: Maternal deaths per 1,00,000 women in the reproductive age group is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal mortality rate

 

The maternal mortality rate refers to the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women of reproductive age (usually between 15 and 49 years) in a given time period. This rate considers the entire population of women in the reproductive age group and not just those giving birth. It helps in assessing the risk associated with pregnancy and childbirth among all women in the reproductive age group.

 

PPH is the most common cause of Maternal mortality in India

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perinatal mortality rate: This rate measures the number of stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life per 1,000 total births. It does not specifically pertain to maternal deaths.

 

Option B. Maternal death rate: Although similar in terminology, this option is not used commonly and does not fit the precise definition provided for maternal mortality metrics.

 

Option D. Maternal mortality ratio: This ratio measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a given time period. It specifically relates to deaths due to complications during pregnancy, childbirth, or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy but does not include the entire reproductive age group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maternal mortality rate measures the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 women in the reproductive age group, focusing on the general population of women of reproductive age rather than only those who have given birth.

questions.text: A lesion involving Brodmann area 22 is most likely to result in which of the following deficits? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Receptive aphasia

 

Broadmann’s area 22 corresponds to Wernicke’s area, which is primarily involved in language comprehension. A lesion in this area leads to receptive aphasia, also known as sensory or Wernicke’s aphasia. In receptive aphasia, patients have difficulty understanding spoken language, and their speech may be fluent but lacks meaning or coherence. They can produce words but often speak in nonsensical phrases or sentences that are difficult to understand, indicating a disruption in the processing of language comprehension.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Poor repetition of language: This is associated with conduction aphasia, which occurs due to a lesion in the arcuate fasciculus that connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. It is characterized by an inability to repeat words or phrases accurately.

 

Option C. Expressive aphasia: This is also known as Broca’s aphasia, resulting from a lesion in Broadmann’s areas 44 and 45. Patients with expressive aphasia have difficulty producing speech, characterized by slow, halting, and effortful speech, but their comprehension remains intact.

 

Option D. Poor naming: Poor naming is typically observed in anomic aphasia, which occurs when the connection between language processing centers is disrupted, but it is not specific to a lesion in Broadmann’s area 22.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in Broadmann’s area 22, known as Wernicke’s area, leads to receptive aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

choices.text: Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)
Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (750/37.5 mg) (2 tablets) + Primaquine 7.5 mg (6 tablets)

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy from Rajasthan weighing 50 kg is diagnosed with mixed P. vivax and P. falciparum malaria. What is the appropriate treatment regimen on day 2?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Artesunate 50 mg (4 tablets) + Primaquine 2.5 mg (6 tablets)

 

In the treatment of malaria, the choice of drugs and regimen depends on the type of malaria (whether it's P. vivax, P. falciparum, or mixed infection) and the geographic location due to different strains' drug resistance profiles. For mixed infections involving P. vivax and P. falciparum, the treatment typically includes a combination of drugs targeting both species.

 

For P. vivax malaria, chloroquine is generally used, followed by primaquine for 14 days to achieve a radical cure by eliminating hypnozoites and preventing relapse. However, in mixed infections and P. falciparum malaria, the treatment regimen includes an Artemisinin-based Combination Therapy (ACT). Specifically, in regions like Rajasthan, ACT comprises artesunate plus sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine.

 

On day 2 of treatment, sulfadoxine/pyrimethamine (which is given only on day 1) has already been administered, so the treatment continues with artesunate and primaquine.

 

Primaquine is dosed at 0.25 mg/kg for 14 days in cases of P. vivax, and the dosage calculated for this patient (weighing 50 kg) is 15 mg/day

 

(0.25 mg/kg × 50 kg = 12.5 mg, rounded to the nearest available tablet strength).

 

The correct regimen on day 2 includes Artesunate (to continue targeting the malaria parasites) and Primaquine (for radical cure and to prevent relapse), specifically at the dosage of 2.5 mg per tablet (6 tablets totaling 15 mg).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malaria Treatment Regimens:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male travels frequently and has food during his travels. He presents to PHC OPD with abdominal pain, fever for 4 days. He has bradycardia too. Test for confirmation of diagnosis: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Blood culture

 

The clinical presentation suggests a diagnosis of enteric fever (typhoid), characterized by abdominal pain, fever, and bradycardia. The appropriate diagnostic test depends on the stage of the illness:

 

Blood culture is the test of choice from the first week of illness onwards. It remains the most reliable test in the initial stages (within the first week of symptoms) to confirm typhoid fever. This test directly detects the presence of Salmonella bacteria in the blood, making it the most accurate diagnostic method during early illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Widal test: This serological test detects antibodies against Salmonella and is typically used from the second week of illness onwards. It is not the preferred test during the first week as antibodies may not yet be present in detectable quantities.

 

Option C. Stool culture: This is used from the third week of illness onwards and detects Salmonella in the gastrointestinal tract. It is not suitable for early diagnosis as it becomes positive later in the disease course.

 

Option D. Urine culture: This is used from the fourth week of illness onwards. It detects Salmonella excreted in the urine, but like stool culture, it is useful later in the course of the disease and not for initial diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For typhoid fever diagnosis in the first week of illness, blood culture is the most appropriate and reliable test.

 

Mnemonic – BASU

 

Blood culture – 1st week onwards

Antibody test (Widal) – 2nd week onwards

Stool culture – 3rd week onwards

Urine culture – 4th week onwards

choices.text: Type 3 has very low levels of vWF

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Von Willebrand Disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 is more severe

 

Von Willebrand Disease (vWD) is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, and it is classified into three main types:

 

  1. Type 1: This is the most common and mildest form, accounting for about 85% of cases. It is characterized by a partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Patients usually have mild bleeding symptoms, and treatment with Desmopressin (DDAVP), which stimulates the release of vWF from endothelial cells, is often effective. Type 1 is not severe, contrary to what option A states.
  2. Type 2: This type involves a qualitative defect in vWF, meaning the protein is present but does not function properly. There are several subtypes (2A, 2B, 2M, 2N), each with distinct functional defects.
  3. Type 3: This is the most severe form of vWD, characterized by a near-total or complete absence of vWF. Patients with Type 3 often have symptoms similar to hemophilia, including severe bleeding and very low levels of factor VIII, since vWF stabilizes and carries factor VIII.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 3 is more severe: This is correct; Type 3 is the most severe form of vWD due to the near-total absence of vWF.

 

Option C. Type 2 is a qualitative defect: This statement is accurate; Type 2 involves a functional abnormality of vWF rather than a quantity issue.

 

Option D. Type 3 has very low levels of vWF: This is true; Type 3 patients have critically low or absent vWF levels, leading to severe bleeding tendencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 1 Von Willebrand Disease is the mildest and most common form, characterized by a partial quantitative deficiency of von Willebrand factor, while Type 3 is the most severe with very low or absent levels of vWF.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient presented with chest pain, shortness of breath, and edema. On examination, his pulse was irregularly irregular, his JVP was elevated and showed a prominent ‘Y’ descent. On auscultation, he had a high-pitched diastolic sound. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Constrictive Pericarditis

 

Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by the thickening and calcification of the pericardium, which restricts diastolic filling of the heart. Key findings in this condition include elevated JVP with a prominent ‘Y’ descent, irregularly irregular pulse, and signs of systemic congestion like edema. The high-pitched diastolic sound referred to as a pericardial knock is characteristic of constrictive pericarditis and reflects the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling.

 

The prominent ‘Y’ descent in JVP is particularly significant in constrictive pericarditis and is also known as Friderich’s sign. This sign, along with the clinical presentation of chest pain, shortness of breath, and irregular pulse suggestive of atrial fibrillation, strongly supports the diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bicuspid Aortic Valve with AR: This condition typically presents with a diastolic murmur and symptoms of heart failure but does not produce a prominent ‘Y’ descent in JVP. The absence of pericardial knock and the presentation with irregularly irregular pulse make this option unlikely.

 

Option B. RHD with MS: Rheumatic heart disease with mitral stenosis typically shows an elevated JVP with prominent ‘a’ waves rather than a ‘Y’ descent. Also, it is associated with a low-pitched diastolic rumble, not a high-pitched sound or pericardial knock.

 

Option D. Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade presents with elevated JVP, but it shows a blunted or absent ‘Y’ descent due to the restricted filling of the heart chambers. The clinical presentation does not align with the typical features of tamponade, such as pulsus paradoxus or muffled heart sounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent ‘Y’ descent in JVP along with a high-pitched diastolic sound (pericardial knock) and symptoms of systemic congestion are hallmark features of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A patient has adult respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is the action of IL-8 in the pathogenesis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neutrophil activation

 

In the pathogenesis of Adult Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), Interleukin-8 (IL-8) plays a crucial role as a potent chemokine that specifically attracts and activates neutrophils.

 

Neutrophil activation is a critical step in the inflammatory cascade that exacerbates endothelial injury and subsequent lung damage in ARDS. Neutrophils, once activated, release proteases, reactive oxygen species, and other inflammatory mediators that contribute to the damage of the alveolar-capillary membrane, further aggravating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelial injury: While endothelial injury is an important early event in ARDS, it is not directly caused by IL-8. Instead, endothelial injury triggers the release of cytokines, including IL-8, which then leads to neutrophil recruitment and activation.

 

Option C. Fibrin deposition: Fibrin deposition is a downstream event in ARDS and is a result of the damage caused by neutrophil activation and endothelial injury. IL-8 indirectly contributes to this through its role in neutrophil activation, but it is not directly responsible for fibrin deposition.

 

Option D. Macrophage activation: While macrophages are involved in the inflammatory response in ARDS, IL-8 primarily targets neutrophils, not macrophages. IL-8's main action is to attract and activate neutrophils rather than macrophages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IL-8 is a key mediator in ARDS that promotes neutrophil activation, which plays a major role in the amplification of inflammation and lung injury in the disease process.

choices.text: It can lead to vision loss
Response to vision symptoms is adjuvant to thyrotoxicosis response
10% of euthyroid patients can have eye involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is false in patients with thyroid eye disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Response to vision symptoms is adjuvant to thyrotoxicosis response

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy, is an autoimmune disorder associated with thyroid dysfunction, most commonly Graves' disease. TED can cause significant eye symptoms independent of thyroid hormone levels.

 

Option B is false because the treatment for vision symptoms in thyroid eye disease is separate from the management of thyrotoxicosis. While controlling thyroid hormone levels is important, the eye manifestations are managed based on the severity of the eye disease. For mild to moderate cases, supportive care, including selenium supplementation, may be helpful. For moderate to severe cases, corticosteroids like dexamethasone or prednisolone are often used, and newer treatments like teprotumumab, an anti-IGF-1 receptor blocker, can be highly effective. Therefore, the response to eye symptoms does not directly correlate with the response to thyroid hormone management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can lead to vision loss: This statement is true. Thyroid eye disease can lead to severe complications, including vision loss due to optic nerve compression or severe corneal exposure.

 

Option C. NOSPECS classification is used: This is correct. The NOSPECS classification system is used to grade the severity of thyroid eye disease, evaluating factors like soft tissue involvement, proptosis, and corneal involvement.

 

Option D. 10% of euthyroid patients can have eye involvement: This is true. Eye involvement in thyroid eye disease can occur even in the absence of abnormal thyroid function tests, a condition referred to as "euthyroid Graves' disease."

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of vision symptoms in thyroid eye disease is distinct and not directly tied to the management of thyrotoxicosis, highlighting the need for tailored therapy based on the eye disease severity.

questions.text: Full form of JSSK is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram


JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram. It was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which was launched in 2005 under the National Rural Health Mission. The older name of JSY was National Maternity Benefit Scheme.

 

Initially, JSY focused only on maternal health, emphasizing the safety and wellbeing of the mother (Janani). However, recognizing the interconnected nature of maternal and newborn health, the program was expanded to include newborn care (Shishu), leading to the creation of JSSK on June 1, 2011 under NRHM. JSSK aims to provide free and cashless services to pregnant women and sick newborns, including transport, medicines, and diet, focusing on enhancing the overall health of both mother and child (upto 1 year of age).

 

Educational Objective:
 

JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram, focusing on the protection and care of both the mother and infant by providing comprehensive healthcare services

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

 

The image presented shows a spine injury, and based on the clinical scenario (a patient presenting after an RTA or road traffic accident), the fracture pattern described fits that of a Chance fracture. A Chance fracture, also known as a flexion-distraction injury or seatbelt fracture, typically occurs due to high-force flexion injuries, such as in a car accident where a seatbelt restrains the lower body while the upper body moves forward. This type of fracture involves a horizontal break extending through all three spinal columns (anterior, middle, and posterior)

 

The Chance fracture goes from anterior to posterior, involving all three columns, which is a hallmark feature of this injury. The description matches the flexion-distraction mechanism associated with this fracture.

 

Additional Information

 

Common spine fractures:

 

  1. Jefferson fracture:
    • Also called a ring fracture of the atlas (C1 vertebra).
    • Mnemonic: JAT.
  2. Hangman's fracture:
    • Fracture through the interarticularis of the C2 vertebra, causing a slip of C2 over C3 (spondylolisthesis).
    • Mnemonic: H2 (Hangman’s fracture, C2 vertebra).
  3. Whiplash injury:
    • Occurs due to hyperextension followed by flexion (e.g., in a high-speed vehicle accident where the vehicle suddenly stops).
    • Resembles the motion of a whiplash.
  4. Wedge fracture:
    • The anterior height of the vertebral body is lowered while the posterior height remains normal.
  5. Burst fracture:
    • Involves damage to the anterior, middle, and posterior columns of the vertebra.
    • The vertebral body is damaged, involving both the anterior and middle columns.
    • Atlas (Jefferson) fracture is also considered a burst fracture.
  6. Chance Fracture:
    • The force moves from anterior to posterior, going all the way to the spinous process.
    • Involves flexion of the body with a distraction force.
    • Also known as jackknife or seatbelt fracture.
  7. Hinge fracture: A fracture where the skull base is divided into two halves: anterior and posterior.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burst fracture: A burst fracture involves damage to the anterior and middle columns of the vertebra, with fragments spreading outwards. While a burst fracture may result from high-energy trauma, the image and clinical description provided in this question are more characteristic of a Chance fracture. The distribution of injury in a burst fracture does not typically extend through all three columns.

 

Option C. Compression fracture: Compression fractures generally affect the anterior part of the vertebra, causing a wedge-shaped deformity, but they do not involve the middle and posterior columns like the Chance fracture. These fractures are often seen in patients with osteoporosis rather than as a result of high-energy trauma.

 

Option D. Fracture of spinous process: A fracture of the spinous process (such as a Clay-shoveler's fracture) usually involves a break in the posterior part of the vertebra only and does not involve the anterior or middle columns. This type of fracture typically occurs from direct trauma or forceful flexion but doesn't match the findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: An image of a perianal disease is shown. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Fistula in Ano


The correct diagnosis is Fistula in Ano. A fistula in ano is an abnormal connection between the interior of the anal canal and the perianal skin. It often presents as a recurrent swelling or abscess near the anal verge, which may drain spontaneously. The key clues include the location of the swelling near the anal verge and the history of recurrent discharge, making it characteristic of a fistula in ano.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pilonidal Sinus: A pilonidal sinus is typically found in the upper part of the natal cleft, far from the anal verge, and is associated with hair follicles in the gluteal region. It commonly affects young men with a hairy back and is located above the coccyx, not near the anus. The key distinction is the location; pilonidal sinuses are not found at the anal verge but higher up in the gluteal cleft.

 

 

Option C. Fissure in Ano: A fissure in ano is a linear tear in the lining of the anus, usually caused by trauma or hard stools. It presents with pain during defecation and bright red bleeding but not with a swelling or external opening as seen in fistula in ano. There may be a hypertrophic skin tag covering it (Sentinel pile). Fissures do not have a history of recurrent discharge or a swelling appearance near the anal verge.

 

 

Option D. Hemorrhoids: Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the rectum or anus and typically present with painless bleeding, itching, and swelling inside the anal canal or at the anal verge. They do not present with the external openings, recurrent abscesses, or discharging sinuses characteristic of fistula in ano.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Fistula in Ano should be considered when there is a history of recurrent swelling, abscess formation, or discharge near the anal verge. It is distinguished from pilonidal sinus by its lower location near the anal canal, as opposed to pilonidal sinuses that occur higher up in the natal cleft.

choices.text: MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks
MTP can be done till 24 weeks
MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk
MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl, a victim of rape, presents at 22 weeks for abortion. What advice will you give her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTP can be done till 24 weeks

 

The MTP Act of 2021 in India allows for abortions b/w 20- 24 weeks in specific cases, including:

 

  • Rape or sexual assault: The girl in the question is a victim of rape, which falls under this category.
  • Risk to maternal life or Disability: If continuing the pregnancy poses a significant risk to the mother's health or life.
  • Substantial fetal anomaly: If the fetus has severe abnormalities incompatible with life or causing significant disability.
  • Minors: The girl is 14 years old, making her a minor, and the law provides special considerations for them.
  • Change in marital status or humanitarian grounds: These are additional situations where MTP may be considered up to 24 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MTP cannot be done as she has crossed 20 weeks: This is incorrect. While the general limit for MTP is 20 weeks, certain circumstances, like rape, allow for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option C. MTP can be done only if the mother's life is at risk: This is partially correct. While risk to the mother's life is a valid reason, it's not the only one. Rape is also a valid indication for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Option D. MTP can only be done if there is a substantial fetal anomaly: Again, this is partially correct. Substantial fetal anomaly is one reason, but rape is another valid reason for MTP up to 24 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In India, under the MTP Act of 2021:

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with fatigue. Labs are as follows - Hb 8 g/dL, WBC 150,000, and platelets 50,000. Examination is significant for hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy is shown. What is the most common karyotypic abnormality? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 46XY t(9;22)

 

The patient's presentation, including significant anemia, leukocytosis, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly, along with the bone marrow biopsy showing blasts with a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm (NC) ratio, scant agranular cytoplasm, and clear cytoplasm, is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

 

  1. Philadelphia Chromosome (t(9;22)): The most common karyotypic abnormality in adults with ALL is the Philadelphia chromosome, which results from the translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, leading to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This mutation is associated with a more aggressive form of ALL and is commonly seen in adult patients.
  2. Cytogenetic Characteristics: The presence of t(9;22) is associated with poor prognosis and requires targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors in addition to standard chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 47 XY +21: This karyotype is seen in Down syndrome, which is associated with an increased risk of ALL, but it is not the most common cytogenetic abnormality in adult ALL.

 

Option C. 45XY t(14;21): This translocation is not associated with ALL

 

Option D. 46XY SRY gene deletion: This option does not relate to ALL

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in adult acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the Philadelphia chromosome, characterized by the t(9;22) translocation leading to the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: Which vitamin can be deficient in a patient who has undergone gastrectomy? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency commonly occurs in patients who have undergone a gastrectomy because the parietal cells of the stomach, which produce intrinsic factor, are removed or significantly reduced. Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot form the necessary complex to be absorbed, leading to deficiency. Conditions such as atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, and autoimmune diseases that affect intrinsic factor can also result in similar deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is usually associated with malabsorption syndromes affecting fat absorption, not specifically with gastrectomy.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C absorption occurs primarily in the small intestine and is not directly affected by the absence of the stomach.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D absorption occurs in the small intestine and depends on fat absorption, which is generally not impacted by gastrectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrectomy can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency due to the loss of intrinsic factor produced by the stomach's parietal cells, which is essential for B12 absorption in the ileum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with fatigue and hemoptysis. His current Hb is 8 g/dL (previous Hb 1 week ago was 12 g/dL). His bronchoalveolar lavage is reddish in color, and his serum creatinine was 1.7 mg/dL. Biopsy of the kidney revealed paucity of immune complexes. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

The clinical presentation suggests a pulmonary-renal syndrome, characterized by symptoms such as hemoptysis, anemia due to pulmonary hemorrhage, and acute kidney injury (indicated by elevated serum creatinine). The biopsy findings showing a paucity of immune complexes indicate that the pathology is not driven by immune complex deposition, ruling out conditions like Goodpasture syndrome, which typically presents with linear IgG deposits.

 

Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is an ANCA-associated vasculitis, which commonly presents as a pulmonary-renal syndrome with diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The absence of immune complexes in the kidney biopsy strongly suggests ANCA-associated vasculitis, specifically MPA, which does not involve immune complex deposition but rather is associated with the presence of ANCA antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: This condition primarily involves progressive lung fibrosis and does not present with hemoptysis, anemia due to alveolar hemorrhage, or renal involvement, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. Hemochromatosis: A condition characterized by iron overload that can affect multiple organs, but it does not typically cause acute pulmonary hemorrhage, sudden anemia, or acute kidney injury as seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that primarily affects the lungs and lymph nodes but does not commonly present with the rapid onset of symptoms such as pulmonary hemorrhage, severe anemia, or renal involvement like those seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is an ANCA-associated vasculitis that often presents with a combination of pulmonary hemorrhage and renal involvement, characterized by a paucity of immune complexes on biopsy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with symptoms of bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal impairment. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a treatment regimen. Which of the following treatments is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bortezomib

 

Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor that is commonly used in the treatment of multiple myeloma. It works by inhibiting the proteasome, which is essential for protein degradation in cells, leading to the accumulation of proteins that induce cell death, particularly in cancer cells. However, Bortezomib is also an immunosuppressant, and one of its known side effects is an increased risk of reactivating latent infections, including herpes zoster (shingles). Herpes zoster is caused by the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, which remains dormant in nerve tissue after an initial chickenpox infection. Immunosuppressive therapies can lower the body's immune response, allowing this virus to reactivate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lenalidomide: While lenalidomide is also used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and has immunomodulatory effects, it is less commonly associated with herpes zoster reactivation compared to Bortezomib.

 

Option C. Daratumumab: This monoclonal antibody targets CD38 on myeloma cells and has a different side effect profile, with a lower risk of herpes zoster reactivation.

 

Option D. Melphalan: Melphalan is an alkylating agent used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, but it is less likely than Bortezomib to cause reactivation of herpes zoster.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bortezomib, a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster due to its immunosuppressive properties. This highlights the importance of monitoring patients on such treatments for signs of viral reactivation

questions.text: A child came with malnutrition and follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions. There was a deficiency of Vitamin A and Essential Fatty Acids. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

 

Phrynoderma, also known as "toad skin," is a type of dermatosis characterized by hyperkeratotic papules that primarily occur over the extensor surfaces such as the elbows and knees. This condition is closely associated with nutritional deficiencies, particularly of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids. In severe cases, deficiencies in other vitamins like Vitamin B complex, Vitamin C, and Vitamin E have also been observed to contribute to this condition.

 

The presentation of follicular hyperkeratotic lesions in a malnourished child, along with documented deficiencies of Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, strongly points to phrynoderma. Recognizing this characteristic presentation is crucial in diagnosing and treating the condition effectively.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin C and is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, bruising, and petechiae, but it does not typically cause follicular hyperkeratotic lesions. Therefore, this is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Option C. Keratosis pilaris: This is a common, benign condition that presents with rough, small, acne-like bumps, typically on the arms, thighs, cheeks, and buttocks. It is not associated with the nutritional deficiencies described in the question, making it an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis (Darier's disease): This is a genetic skin disorder characterized by greasy, warty papules and plaques in seborrheic areas like the scalp, forehead, upper arms, chest, and back. It is not associated with vitamin deficiencies or malnutrition, which makes it an in Ans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrynoderma is associated with malnutrition and deficiencies in Vitamin A and essential fatty acids, and it presents with follicular hyperkeratotic skin lesions, particularly over the elbows and knees.

choices.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

 

The Ans. is 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, which is the location known as the flexion point. The flexion point is critical in vacuum-assisted deliveries because it lies 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle on the baby's head. This point is chosen because pulling on this location causes flexion of the baby's head, facilitating the proper positioning for delivery. Flexion is crucial as it allows the smallest diameter of the baby's head to present, making the delivery process smoother and safer for both the mother and baby.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.

choices.text: Loss of sensation on forehead and dorsum of nose
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx

questions.text: What will be the clinical presentation if the nerve passing through the marked region has been injured? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of sensation on forehead and dorsum of nose

 

The marked region in the provided images corresponds to the superior orbital fissure, a key anatomical opening through which several cranial nerves pass. Among these, the frontal nerve, a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, passes through this fissure. The frontal nerve further divides into the supratrochlear and supraorbital nerves, which supply sensation to the forehead and dorsum of the nose. Injury to this nerve results in loss of sensation in these areas.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of sensation in jaw area: This area is primarily innervated by the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, specifically the inferior alveolar, mental, and buccal nerves, which do not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Therefore, an injury to the nerve passing through the fissure would not affect sensation in the jaw area.

 

Option C. Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face: The maxillary area is innervated by the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve, which exits through the foramen rotundum, not the superior orbital fissure. Thus, injury at the superior orbital fissure would not impact this area.

 

Option D. Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx: This region is primarily innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and branches of the vagus nerve, which do not pass through the superior orbital fissure, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:


The superior orbital fissure allows the passage of nerves that supply sensation to the forehead and dorsum of the nose, including the frontal nerve, whose injury leads to sensory loss in these regions.

questions.text: Drug contraindicated in asthma in PPH (Postpartum Hemorrhage) case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carboprost

 

Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha analog that is commonly used to manage atonic postpartum hemorrhage by inducing strong uterine contractions. However, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction and exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Carboprost is also contraindicated in patients with cardiac arrhythmias due to its potent cardiovascular effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyl ergometrine: This drug is used for the management of postpartum hemorrhage due to its uterotonic properties, but it does not specifically affect asthma and is not contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, is also used in postpartum hemorrhage for uterine contraction. It does not have the same bronchoconstrictive effects as Carboprost and is not contraindicated in asthma.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a common uterotonic agent used in postpartum hemorrhage management. It has no known bronchoconstrictive properties and is safe for use in asthmatic patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carboprost (PGF2 alpha) is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to its bronchoconstrictive effects.

questions.text: During a health education session, people cannot understand your few technical words during the chat, and it’s a miscommunication. This is which type of barrier? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Semantic barrier


A semantic barrier, also known as a linguistic barrier, arises when there is a difference in language or when technical jargon and complex terms are used that the audience cannot understand. This leads to miscommunication because the message is not clearly conveyed. In the given scenario, the use of technical words during the health education session caused a communication breakdown because the audience did not understand those terms. This is a classic example of a semantic barrier.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cultural barrier: A cultural barrier occurs when differences in customs, beliefs, caste or religion prevent effective communication. This is not the case here as the issue was related to language and technical terms, not cultural differences.

 

Option B. Physiological barrier: Physiological barriers include physical issues like hearing difficulties or speech impairments that obstruct communication. These are not relevant to the scenario described, where language misunderstanding was the primary issue.

 

Option C. Psychological barrier: Psychological barriers stem from emotional disturbances, stress, or mental conditions that hinder effective communication. While these can affect communication, they are unrelated to the miscommunication caused by technical words in this example.

 

Educational Objective:


A semantic barrier occurs when the use of complex language, technical terms, or unfamiliar words leads to misunderstanding and miscommunication.

choices.text: Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse
Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output

questions.text: In a patient on mechanical ventilation and placed in prone position which of the following about PEEP is true? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents atelectasis of lung and alveolar collapse

 

Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) is a crucial component of mechanical ventilation, particularly in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or other conditions leading to alveolar collapse. PEEP works by maintaining a certain amount of pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration, which helps to keep the alveoli open, preventing their collapse (atelectasis). This is especially important in the prone position, where the distribution of ventilation can be more uniform, improving oxygenation and lung mechanics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduces CO2 in alveoli: This option is incorrect because the primary role of PEEP is not to reduce CO2 levels in the alveoli but to prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. CO2 removal is more dependent on ventilation rate and tidal volume.

 

Option C. Decreases inspiratory pressure: This option is incorrect because PEEP typically increases the baseline pressure in the lungs, which can actually increase the overall mean airway pressure during inspiration. It does not decrease inspiratory pressure.

 

Option D. Increases venous return and thus maintains cardiac output: This option is incorrect because, in fact, PEEP can decrease venous return due to the increased intrathoracic pressure it creates. This decrease in venous return can lead to a reduction in cardiac output, especially in patients with pre-existing cardiovascular compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PEEP is primarily used to prevent alveolar collapse (atelectasis) and maintain lung recruitment, especially in conditions like ARDS or when the patient is positioned prone during mechanical ventilation.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic side wall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cervical cancer. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3B

 

Stage 3B cervical cancer is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic side wall and the presence of hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to ureteric obstruction. In this stage, the cancer has extended to the lateral pelvic wall, and often the tumor affects the ureter, leading to obstructive uropathy. This progression indicates a significant local spread of the disease, distinguishing it from earlier stages where cancer is confined closer to the cervix or upper parts of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2B: Stage 2B cervical cancer involves the spread of cancer into the parametrium but does not reach the lateral pelvic wall. It does not involve hydronephrosis or ureteric obstruction, which are key features distinguishing Stage 3B.

 

Option B. 3A: Stage 3A involves the spread of cancer to the lower third of the vagina without extension to the pelvic wall or causing hydronephrosis. It does not involve the pelvic side wall or ureteric complications, unlike Stage 3B.

 

Option D. 3C: Stage 3C is characterized by the spread of cancer to pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes but does not necessarily involve the pelvic side wall or hydronephrosis. Stage 3C is further divided into 3C1 (pelvic lymph nodes) and 3C2 (para-aortic lymph nodes), differing from the pelvic side wall involvement seen in Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of cervical cancer:

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with sudden breathlessness. X-ray of the patient is shown. What is likely to be heard on auscultation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent sounds

 

The patient presents with sudden breathlessness, and the X-ray reveals signs consistent with pneumothorax, including a collapsed lung with hyperlucent areas in the pleural space. Pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse and preventing normal lung expansion. In tension pneumothorax, there may also be a shift of the trachea and mediastinum due to increased pressure.

 

On auscultation, absent or significantly reduced breath sounds are typically heard on the affected side due to the collapse of the lung and the presence of air in the pleural space preventing sound transmission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesicular: Vesicular breath sounds are normal sounds heard over healthy lung tissue. They are soft and low-pitched. In the case of pneumothorax, these sounds would not be heard over the affected area because the lung is collapsed.

 

Option B. Bronchial: Bronchial breath sounds are usually heard over the trachea and are high-pitched with a distinct pause between inspiration and expiration. These sounds are not typically heard in pneumothorax; instead, there would be absent or reduced breath sounds due to the collapse of the lung.

 

Option D. Bronchovesicular: These sounds are intermediate between bronchial and vesicular and are typically heard over the main bronchi. In pneumothorax, however, breath sounds would be absent or reduced on the affected side, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumothorax is characterized by absent or reduced breath sounds on the affected side during auscultation due to the collapse of the lung.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency room with severe pain in the abdomen. Serum triglyceride level was 1500 mg/dL. Identify the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apo CII

 

The clinical presentation of severe abdominal pain and extremely elevated triglyceride levels (1500 mg/dL) suggests acute pancreatitis secondary to hypertriglyceridemia, commonly seen in Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia. This condition is characterized by a defect in the lipoprotein lipase (LPL) enzyme or its activator, Apo CII. Apo CII is essential for the activation of LPL, which breaks down triglycerides in the blood. A deficiency or defect in Apo CII prevents this activation, leading to the accumulation of triglycerides and increased risk of pancreatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Apo B 48: This apolipoprotein is essential for the formation of chylomicrons but does not play a role in lipase activation or triglyceride breakdown. Defects in Apo B 48 do not cause elevated triglyceride levels seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Apo B 100: Apo B 100 is critical for the formation of LDL and VLDL particles but does not contribute directly to triglyceride metabolism or cause the acute elevation of triglycerides leading to pancreatitis.

 

Option D. LDL receptor: Defects in LDL receptors are associated with familial hypercholesterolemia, leading to elevated LDL cholesterol levels, not triglycerides. It does not contribute to the type of severe hypertriglyceridemia seen in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia, presenting with high triglycerides and abdominal pain, is often due to a defect in lipoprotein lipase or its activator, Apo CII.

questions.text: A patient had a pulmonary mass which shows IHC staining with TTF-1 as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma lung

 

Thyroid Transcription Factor-1 (TTF-1) is a nuclear protein that is a specific marker for adenocarcinoma of the lung and small cell carcinoma of the lung. However, it is most commonly associated with adenocarcinoma.

 

TTF-1 positivity indicates that the tumor cells are likely of lung or thyroid origin, with adenocarcinoma being the most common type of lung cancer associated with this marker.

 

Additionally, other markers like Napsin A and surfactant protein A1 are also specific to adenocarcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell cancer lung: Squamous cell carcinoma typically shows markers like P63, P40, or keratin. It does not stain positive for TTF-1, differentiating it from adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma lung: While TTF-1 can be positive in small cell carcinoma, other specific markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin, and INSM-1 are more indicative. TTF-1's presence alone, along with the given context, makes adenocarcinoma the more likely diagnosis.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma lung: This is generally a diagnosis of exclusion and does not have specific immunohistochemical markers like TTF-1. Large cell carcinoma is generally a diagnosis of exclusion, as it lacks specific markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TTF-1 is a key immunohistochemical marker that strongly suggests adenocarcinoma of the lung, particularly when observed in a pulmonary mass.

questions.text: Following is the x-ray of an 18-year-old boy who complains of fever, pain in the lower limb, local rise of temperature, and tenderness in the area shown. On investigation, he has increased ESR. What can be the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ewing's sarcoma

 

  • This case presents a teenager (18-year-old) with symptoms of fever, pain, local rise in temperature, and tenderness in the lower limb, along with increased ESR are suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Radiological features:
    • The first image shows a layered periosteal reaction (onion-skin appearance), which is characteristic of Ewing's sarcoma.
    • The second and third images show a permeative pattern of bone destruction with a soft tissue mass, another hallmark of Ewing's sarcoma.
  • Ewing's sarcoma typically affects children and adolescents (common in ages 10–20).
  • Symptoms include localized pain, swelling, fever, and elevated ESR, often mimicking infection like osteomyelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Germ cell tumor: Germ cell tumors typically arise in the reproductive organs (testes or ovaries) or occasionally outside these locations (extragonadal). It is not typically a primary bone tumor and doesn't fit the radiographic pattern.

 

Option B. Osteomyelitis: Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone and can cause fever, pain, and elevated ESR, mimicking the symptoms of this case. However, osteomyelitis is more likely to show a solid periosteal reaction or sequestra on x-ray. Osteomyelitis may look similar clinically but rarely shows onion-skin periosteal reaction.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is another malignant bone tumor that commonly presents with a sunburst appearance and Codman’s triangle on x-ray. However, osteosarcoma typically arises in the metaphysis (the wide part at the ends of bones), particularly in the distal femur or proximal tibia, rather than the diaphysis. It usually presents with pain and swelling but not systemic signs like fever and high ESR to this extent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ewing’s sarcoma typically presents in the diaphysis of long bones in children and adolescents, with a onion skin periosteal reaction seen on x-ray.

questions.text: Identify the prolapse?(NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grade 3 prolapse with cystocele

 

The image shows a Grade 3 prolapse with cystocele, based on the old classification system  classification). In this grading system:

 

  • Grade 1: Prolapse remains inside the vagina.
  • Grade 2: Prolapse reaches the introitus but does not protrude outside.
  • Grade 3: Prolapse extends outside the introitus but not entirely out, and can include anterior vaginal wall prolapse as seen with cystocele.
  • Grade 4 (Procedentia): The entire uterus is outside the introitus.

 

The observed prolapse primarily shows the anterior vaginal wall protruding, indicating a cystocele. A distinguishing feature between Grade 3 and Grade 4 prolapse is the thumb-finger test: if the thumb and finger can approximate over the swelling completely, it indicates Grade 4 prolapse; otherwise, it is Grade 3.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 3 prolapse with rectocele: This option is incorrect because the protrusion is primarily from the anterior wall, characteristic of a cystocele, not a rectocele (posterior wall).

 

Option C. Grade 2 prolapse with cystocele: This is incorrect as Grade 2 would not extend outside the introitus, whereas the prolapse seen here is visibly beyond the introitus.

 

Option D. Grade 2 prolapse with rectocele: This option is incorrect for the same reasons as Grade 2 cystocele; additionally, the prolapse involves the anterior wall rather than the posterior, ruling out rectocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade 3 prolapse extends outside the introitus and can involve cystocele. Differentiating between Grade 3 and Grade 4 requires the thumb-finger approximation test.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of unexplained weight loss, hematuria, and a palpable abdominal mass. Imaging studies reveal a large renal mass. A renal biopsy has the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromophobe carcinoma

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings are consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). Chromophobe RCC is characterized histologically by large polygonal cells with distinct cell borders, perinuclear halos, and a "plant-like" or "resinoid" nuclear appearance.

 

The biopsy image shows these classic features, which differentiate chromophobe RCC from other renal cancer variants.

 

While clear cell carcinoma is the most common type of RCC, the histological findings of clear cytoplasm with perinuclear clearing are more characteristic of chromophobe carcinoma. This variant is less aggressive compared to clear cell RCC and is often diagnosed with specific features on histopathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clear cell carcinoma: This is the most common type of RCC, characterized by cells with clear cytoplasm due to the presence of glycogen and lipid, which are dissolved during processing. The biopsy image does not show these clear cells, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary RCC is characterized by the presence of papillary structures and foamy macrophages. The biopsy image lacks these papillary features, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option D. Bellini duct carcinoma: Also known as collecting duct carcinoma, this rare and aggressive form of RCC shows infiltrative growth patterns with prominent desmoplastic reaction. The biopsy does not match these characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromophobe RCC is identified by cells with distinct borders, a plant-like or resinoid nucleus, and a perinuclear halo, distinguishing it from other RCC types.

choices.text: EMLA means equal mixture of LA
Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream
1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream 

 

The cream shown in the image is EMLA cream, which is a topical anesthetic. EMLA cream contains a combination of two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, in a 1:1 ratio. One of the known complications of EMLA cream is methemoglobinemia. This condition can occur, especially when the cream is used in large quantities or in patients with certain predispositions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMLA means equal mixture of LA: EMLA means Eutectic mixture of LA and not equal mixture of LA.

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine: This option is incorrect because EMLA cream does not contain ropivacaine. The active ingredients in EMLA cream are lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine.

 

Option D. 1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg: This option is also incorrect. 1 gram of EMLA 5% cream contains 25mg of lidocaine and 25mg of prilocaine, not 50mg of lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream can cause methemoglobinemia as a complication, especially when used inappropriately or in large quantities.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male came with complaints of orange hue over the body with hyperkeratotic perifollicular erythematous papules associated with scaling, which started near the face and slowly progressed to involve the entire body. Islands of sparing noted over the body. Palmoplantar keratoderma noted. Histology shows alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris (PRP) is a rare skin disorder characterized by orange-red plaques, hyperkeratotic follicular papules, and scaling that typically starts on the face and progresses caudally (cephalocaudal spread) to involve the entire body.

 

A hallmark feature is the presence of “islands of sparing,” where patches of normal skin are surrounded by erythematous areas. The thickening of the skin over the palms and soles, known as palmoplantar keratoderma, is another distinguishing feature of PRP.

Histologically, PRP shows a distinctive pattern known as the "checkerboard" pattern, characterized by alternating areas of orthokeratosis (normal keratinization) and parakeratosis (abnormal keratinization).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycosis fungoides: Mycosis fungoides is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that typically presents as patchy erythematous lesions, often resembling eczema or psoriasis, but it does not exhibit the cephalocaudal spread or islands of sparing characteristic of PRP. The histological findings also differ, with atypical lymphocytes being a hallmark of mycosis fungoides rather than the checkerboard pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option B. Follicular psoriasis: Psoriasis, including its follicular variant, usually presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered by silvery scales. While it may involve the palms and soles, the orange hue, islands of sparing, and cephalocaudal spread are not typical of psoriasis. Histologically, psoriasis shows uniform parakeratosis and elongation of the rete ridges rather than the alternating pattern seen in PRP.

 

Option D. Keratosis follicularis: Also known as Darier's disease, keratosis follicularis presents with greasy, warty papules, often in seborrheic areas. It lacks the distinctive orange hue, islands of sparing, and palmoplantar keratoderma seen in PRP. Histologically, Darier’s disease shows suprabasal acantholysis and dyskeratosis rather than the orthokeratosis and parakeratosis found in PRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pityriasis Rubra Pilaris is characterized by an orange-red hue with cephalocaudal spread, islands of sparing, palmoplantar keratoderma, and a histological "checkerboard" pattern of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

questions.text: Following images show the sample collected from a patient complaining of perianal itching. The diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enterobius vermicularis

 

Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm, is the most common cause of perianal itching, especially in children. This worm lays its eggs around the perianal region, which leads to intense itching. The characteristic D-shaped (plano-convex) eggs seen in the images further confirm the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis. The images depict the typical appearance of the worm’s head and its eggs, which have a clear, thick shell with one flattened side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma: Ancylostoma, also known as hookworm, typically causes symptoms like iron deficiency anemia due to blood loss from the intestines. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are not D-shaped.

 

Option C. H Nana: Hymenolepis nana, the dwarf tapeworm, causes hymenolepiasis, which can present with gastrointestinal symptoms but not specifically perianal itching. Its eggs are spherical with polar filaments, which are distinctly different from the D-shaped eggs of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is another type of hookworm that primarily causes symptoms related to iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal discomfort. It does not typically cause perianal itching, and its eggs are oval with a thin, smooth shell, different from those of Enterobius vermicularis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterobius vermicularis is associated with perianal itching and produces characteristic D-shaped eggs.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis with high anion gap
Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis with low anion gap

questions.text: Evaluate the arterial blood gas with the following findings: pH 7.26, PaCO₂ - 16 mm Hg, HCO₃ - 8, Na⁺ 135, Cl⁻ - 108, K⁺ - 4.2. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis with high anion gap

 

The patient's ABG shows a pH of 7.26, indicating acidosis. Both the PaCO₂ and bicarbonate (HCO₃) levels are decreased, aligning with the pattern seen in metabolic acidosis. According to the Rome rule, when the pH, PaCO₂, and HCO₃ all move in the same direction, it points toward a metabolic process—in this case, metabolic acidosis.

 

To confirm the presence of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), the anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

 

Since the anion gap is 19 (normal is usually 8-12), this confirms a high anion gap, indicating that the acidosis is due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions. The low PaCO₂ (16 mm Hg) suggests that the body is compensating for the metabolic acidosis through respiratory alkalosis by blowing off CO₂.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis with low anion gap: Respiratory acidosis would present with elevated PaCO₂, not decreased, and compensation would involve increased bicarbonate, not decreased. The scenario presented does not fit this pattern.

 

Option C. Metabolic alkalosis: This would present with an elevated pH, elevated bicarbonate, and often an elevated PaCO₂ due to compensatory hypoventilation. None of these findings align with the presented ABG values.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis would show a high pH with a low PaCO₂, and compensation would involve a drop in bicarbonate. While the PaCO₂ is low, the overall pH is acidic, indicating the primary disturbance is not respiratory alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a low pH, decreased bicarbonate, and decreased PaCO₂ with a calculated high anion gap strongly indicates high anion gap metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

choices.text: Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness
Activates locus coeruleus and cause wakefulness
No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep
Activates histamine release and prevents sleep

questions.text: A man habitually consumes coffee before bedtime and claims difficulty in sleep during night. What is the role of caffeine in wakefulness? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blocks adenosine action and causes wakefulness

 

Caffeine is a stimulant that is commonly consumed to reduce fatigue and increase alertness. Its primary mechanism of action in promoting wakefulness is through blocking the action of adenosine, a neurotransmitter in the brain that promotes sleep and relaxation by binding to adenosine receptors. Normally, when adenosine binds to its receptors, it leads to drowsiness and a decrease in nerve cell activity. Caffeine, due to its structural similarity to adenosine, competes for these receptors but does not activate them. Instead, it blocks the action of adenosine, preventing the onset of sleepiness and promoting wakefulness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activates locus coeruleus and causes wakefulness: The locus coeruleus is a nucleus in the brainstem involved in physiological responses to stress and panic, and it is active during REM sleep to help regulate wakefulness. However, caffeine does not directly activate the locus coeruleus to cause wakefulness; instead, its wakefulness-promoting effect is primarily through adenosine receptor blockade.

 

Option C. No role in maintaining wakefulness if taken 1hr before sleep: This statement is incorrect because caffeine does play a significant role in maintaining wakefulness even if consumed an hour before sleep. Caffeine has a half-life of about 5-6 hours, meaning it remains active in the system for several hours after consumption, potentially leading to difficulty falling asleep.

 

Option D. Activates histamine release and prevents sleep: Histamine is a neurotransmitter involved in wakefulness, but caffeine does not exert its wakefulness-promoting effects through histamine release. The primary mechanism is through blocking adenosine receptors, not activating histamine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily by blocking adenosine receptors in the brain, thereby preventing the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine.
