Option C. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid): EDTA is not commonly used for iron overdose, as its primary use is in chelating lead and other heavy metals. While it is not the preferred treatment for iron poisoning, it is not specifically contraindicated as BAL is.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because Desferrioxamine is actually the treatment of choice for iron overdose, and EDTA can be used in some cases if Desferrioxamine is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAL is contraindicated in iron overdose due to its potential to form harmful complexes, making Desferrioxamine the preferred treatment in such cases.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. A biopsy is obtained and it is as shown below. Flow cytometry showed the following findings: Tdt – negative, CD5/CD23 – negative, CD10/CD19/CD20, and SIg are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burkitt’s lymphoma

 

The biopsy and flow cytometry findings are consistent with Burkitt’s lymphoma, which is a high-grade B-cell lymphoma commonly seen in children and young adults. The characteristic features include negative Tdt, negative CD5, and CD23, with positive CD10, CD19, CD20, and surface immunoglobulin (SIg). The biopsy often shows a "starry sky" appearance due to macrophages with ingested apoptotic cells. These findings, along with the age and presentation, strongly suggest Burkitt’s lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DLBCL (Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma): DLBCL is more common in adults and typically presents as a rapidly growing mass, but it is not commonly seen in young children like this patient. Flow cytometry findings do not specifically point to DLBCL, making it a less likely diagnosis in this context.

 

Option C. ALCL (Anaplastic Large Cell Lymphoma): ALCL is usually characterized by ALK positivity and CD30 positivity. The absence of ALK and CD30 markers, which are key for diagnosing ALCL, rules this option out.

 

Option D. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): ALL is ruled out primarily due to the negative Tdt, a marker typically positive in ALL. Additionally, ALL would present with different immunophenotypic markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt’s lymphoma should be considered in young patients presenting with cervical lymphadenopathy and specific flow cytometry findings including negative Tdt and positive CD10, CD19, CD20, and SIg.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enlarged blind spots

 

The correct answer is Enlarged blind spots. The image shows a significant enlargement of the physiological blind spot, which is a hallmark of conditions such as papilledema. Papilledema is a condition characterized by optic disc swelling due to increased intracranial pressure. This swelling leads to an enlarged blind spot-on visual field testing, which is prominently seen in the images provided.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Altitudinal field defects: These defects present as a loss of vision above or below the horizontal line, resembling a band-like defect across the visual field. This type of defect is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy or branch retinal artery or vein occlusion.

 

 

Option C. Arcuate field defects: Arcuate defects appear as arc-shaped visual losses that extend from the blind spot and follow the nerve fiber layer pattern. This type of defect is typically seen in glaucoma and other optic neuropathies.

 

 

Option D. Roennes nasal step: This defect is characterized by a step-like pattern near the nasal visual field, commonly seen in glaucoma. It occurs due to the asymmetry between the superior and inferior nerve fiber bundles

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enlarged blind spots on visual field testing are indicative of conditions like papilledema, where optic disc swelling leads to an increased physiological blind spot

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman in her second pregnancy is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at 30 weeks gestation. What is the drug of choice for her treatment? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin)

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). LMWH is the preferred treatment for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) during pregnancy due to its safety profile and ease of monitoring. LMWH does not cross the placenta, making it safer for the fetus compared to other anticoagulants. Additionally, LMWH requires less frequent monitoring compared to unfractionated heparin, making it more convenient for both patients and healthcare providers during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin is contraindicated in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can lead to fetal complications, including congenital malformations and bleeding. Warfarin is generally reserved for patients with specific conditions such as mechanical heart valves who were already on the drug before pregnancy, under careful supervision.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: While Fondaparinux is an anticoagulant, it is not the first-line choice for DVT in pregnancy. It is generally considered when LMWH is contraindicated, such as in cases of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

 

Option D. Apixaban: Apixaban, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), is not recommended in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data. DOACs are generally avoided during pregnancy because they can cross the placenta and pose risks to the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, the drug of choice for treating DVT is Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) due to its safety and ease of monitoring compared to other anticoagulants

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with progressive muscle weakness, particularly affecting the eyes and throat, leading to difficulty with swallowing and drooping eyelids. Imaging studies reveal a mediastinal mass. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The patient's symptoms of progressive muscle weakness, especially involving the eyes and throat, suggest myasthenia gravis, a condition commonly associated with thymoma. Thymomas are the most common type of anterior mediastinal mass and are frequently linked with autoimmune conditions like myasthenia gravis. In this case, the imaging reveals a mediastinal mass, which strongly indicates thymoma given the clinical context. Thymomas typically present as homogeneous, hypodense masses on imaging, though they lack specific features. Additionally, thymomas can be associated with other conditions such as pure red cell aplasia and Goode's syndrome (hypogammaglobulinemia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PTH adenoma: Parathyroid adenomas are not associated with myasthenia gravis or mediastinal masses. They usually present with hypercalcemia-related symptoms and are not linked to muscle weakness or drooping eyelids.

 

Option C. Teratoma: Teratomas are also anterior mediastinal masses but are generally associated with more variable imaging features, including cystic or calcified components. They do not have a direct association with myasthenia gravis or the specific clinical symptoms presented.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: While lymphoma can present as a mediastinal mass, it usually presents with systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss. It is not specifically associated with myasthenia gravis or the described muscle weakness and drooping eyelids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most common anterior mediastinal mass associated with myasthenia gravis, presenting with symptoms like progressive muscle weakness, difficulty swallowing, and drooping eyelids.

questions.text: In Demographic cycle, B curve represents: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Death rate

 

In the demographic cycle, the B curve represents the death rate (Crude Death Rate - CDR). The demographic cycle is divided into five stages, which are primarily determined by birth and death rates:

 

  1. Stage 1 (High Stationary): Both the birth rate (A) and the death rate (B) are high, resulting in a stable population.
  2. Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The birth rate (A) remains high while the death rate (B) starts to decline due to improved medical facilities, causing the population to increase.
  3. Stage 3 (Late Expanding): Both birth and death rates start declining, often due to the introduction of family planning and other socio-economic factors. India is currently in this stage.
  4. Stage 4 (Low Stationary): Both rates decline to a low level, stabilizing the population growth.
  5. Stage 5 (Declining): The birth rate drops below the death rate, leading to a reduction in population size.

 

In this context, Curve B clearly represents the death rate as it follows the pattern of decline in stages 2 and 3, stabilizes in stage 4, and may increase slightly in stage 5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Incorrect. Curve A represents the birth rate (Crude Birth Rate - CBR), which remains high initially but starts to decline from stage 3 onwards.

 

Option C. Growth rate: Incorrect. Growth rate is not directly shown on the graph; it is inferred from the difference between birth and death rates.

 

Option D. Total population: Incorrect. Curve C represents the total population, which increases as the death rate declines and stabilizes when both rates are low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The B curve in the demographic cycle represents the death rate, which declines significantly from stage 2 due to improved healthcare and stabilizes in later stages.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presented with shortness of breath, and further evaluation revealed a right pleural effusion. Upon analysis, pleural fluid showed LDH that is 0.7 times the serum LDH and protein that is 0.6 times the serum protein. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The pleural fluid values provided are consistent with an exudative effusion based on Light’s criteria:

 

  • Light’s Criteria for Exudative Effusion (any one of the following):
  • Pleural fluid protein / serum protein ratio > 0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH ratio > 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 the upper limit of normal serum LDH
  • This case satisfies both the first and second criteria:
  • Protein ratio = 0.6 > 0.5
  • LDH ratio = 0.7 > 0.6

 

Therefore, it is an exudative effusion.

 

Tuberculosis is a common cause of exudative pleural effusion, especially in endemic areas like India. The effusion is typically lymphocyte predominant and due to pleural inflammation and increased capillary permeability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart failure: Commonly causes transudative effusion due to increased hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option C. Hepatic failure: Usually results in transudative effusion, especially in cirrhosis (hepatic hydrothorax), due to low oncotic pressure.

 

Option D. Renal failure: Leads to transudative effusion due to fluid overload or low albumin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis causes exudative pleural effusions due to pleural inflammation. In contrast, heart failure, hepatic failure, and renal failure typically cause transudative effusions.

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Placenta accrete syndrome


Placenta accrete syndrome (PAS) includes conditions where the placenta abnormally attaches to the uterus, such as placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. In this case, the image and description of the uterus with the placenta still attached indicate PAS. The typical presentation involves severe intraoperative bleeding because the placenta does not detach easily from the uterine wall, necessitating an obstetric hysterectomy to control the hemorrhage. This condition is common in patients with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) due to scarring in the uterine wall, making placental attachment more likely. Diagnosing PAS antenatally can alter management strategies, such as planning an elective upper segment cesarean section between 34-37 weeks and avoiding the lower uterine segment to minimize bleeding and complications. After delivering the baby, the placenta should be left in situ, followed by an immediate obstetric hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, leading to painless bleeding during pregnancy but not typically associated with an adherent placenta that requires hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves premature placental detachment from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding. However, it does not involve a placenta that remains attached and does not generally necessitate a hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, often resulting from previous uterine surgeries. It presents with acute pain and significant bleeding, but the description and image do not match the typical findings of PAS.

 

Educational Objective:


Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

questions.text: Components of Disaster cycle that can be included in the recovery phase are: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction

 

 

The disaster cycle consists of several phases: impact, response, rehabilitation, reconstruction, mitigation, and preparedness.

 

The recovery phase specifically focuses on restoring the affected area to normalcy and includes three key components: Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction (Mnemonic: 3Rs). These steps are crucial for rebuilding after a disaster, addressing immediate needs (response), restoring essential services (rehabilitation), and rebuilding infrastructure (reconstruction).

 

Educational Objective:
 

The recovery phase of the disaster cycle includes the components of Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction, which are essential for restoring the community post-disaster.

questions.text: Identify the stage of the pressure sore:  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

A stage 4 pressure sore is characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. The image shows a deep ulcer with visible bone and extensive tissue damage, which are hallmarks of a stage 4 pressure sore. This stage represents the most severe form of pressure ulcer, with significant risk for infection and complications due to the depth of tissue involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: This stage involves non-blanching erythema of intact skin. It is the earliest stage of pressure ulceration, where the skin appears red and does not turn white when pressed.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 pressure sores involve partial-thickness skin loss with exposure of the dermis. They may appear as shallow, open ulcers with a red or pink wound bed, without slough or deeper tissue exposure.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 sores show full-thickness skin loss, where subcutaneous fat may be visible but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed. The ulcer may include undermining and tunneling but does not extend into deeper structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 4 pressure sores are the most advanced, involving full-thickness tissue loss with visible bone, muscle, or tendon. Early identification and treatment of pressure sores can prevent progression to this severe stage.

questions.text: A mother brought her 2-year-old child to the OPD with complaints of lack of weight gain, abdominal pain on eating, and poor eating habits. The child was advised to follow a gluten-free diet, after which there was an improvement in the general condition and weight gain. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Celiac disease

 

The child’s symptoms of abdominal pain on eating, poor weight gain, and the significant improvement in condition and weight after adopting a gluten-free diet strongly suggest celiac disease. Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. The most effective screening test is the anti-TTG IgA test, and the gold standard for diagnosis is endoscopy with biopsy. Although a biopsy is the gold standard, it may overlap with other diseases; however, in the context of a gluten-free diet response, celiac disease is the most probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tropical sprue: Tropical sprue is typically seen in individuals living in tropical regions and is often considered a diagnosis of exclusion. It presents with symptoms similar to celiac disease but usually involves vitamin B12 deficiency and does not respond specifically to a gluten-free diet.

 

Option C. Abetalipoproteinemia: Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by neurological symptoms, growth retardation, and vitamin deficiencies such as vitamin A deficiency causing night blindness. Patients may have characteristic acanthocytes on a blood smear, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option D. Whipple disease: Whipple disease is a rare bacterial infection that presents with more complex symptoms such as dementia, cardiac involvement, and gastrointestinal disturbances. The patient does not display the classic symptoms of Whipple disease, such as dementia or cardiac issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Celiac disease should be suspected in patients with symptoms of gastrointestinal distress, poor weight gain, and improvement upon adopting a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with eclampsia is on a maintenance dose of MgSO₄. When will you stop MgSO₄? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine output 60ml in 4hr


Magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) is used in eclampsia management to prevent seizures. However, MgSO₄ toxicity can occur, which necessitates stopping or adjusting the dose. The first sign of MgSO₄ toxicity is the absence of deep tendon reflexes (DTRs), followed by respiratory depression and reduced urine output. Since magnesium is excreted through the kidneys, urine output is a critical measure of magnesium toxicity risk. A urine output of less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours) indicates poor excretion and potential toxicity, requiring immediate adjustment or cessation of MgSO₄.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee jerk present: The presence of a knee jerk (deep tendon reflex) is a positive sign and indicates that magnesium levels are not yet toxic. The absence of DTRs is the first indication of toxicity, so this is not a reason to stop MgSO₄.

 

Option B. RR 18/min: A respiratory rate above 10 breaths per minute is safe when on MgSO₄. Respiratory depression is a sign of advanced toxicity; therefore, a rate of 18 per minute is not concerning.

 

Option C. Visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are symptoms associated with eclampsia or pre-eclampsia (e.g., retinal detachment or blurred vision) but are not signs of MgSO₄ toxicity. These do not indicate the need to stop MgSO₄.

 

Educational Objective:


MgSO₄ should be stopped if the patient’s urine output is less than 30 ml per hour (or 60 ml in 4 hours), as this indicates poor excretion and risk of magnesium toxicity.

questions.text: Patient can see 3 green dots on the Worth’s 4 dots test. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RE suppression

 

The Worth 4-dot test is used to evaluate binocular vision and identify suppression of one eye or diplopia. The patient wears red-green goggles where the Red lens is over the Right eye (RE) and the green lens is over the left eye (LE). Normally, a person should see four dots: one red, two green, and one white dot that appears either as red, green, or mixed (brown), depending on which eye is dominant or if both eyes are functioning equally.

 

If a patient sees only three green dots, it indicates suppression of the right eye (RE). This is because the right eye, which should see the red dot, is not contributing to the vision, leading the patient to perceive only the green dots seen by the left eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crossed diplopia: In crossed diplopia, images from the right eye appear on the left side and vice versa, causing overlapping images. This does not match the scenario where only three green dots are seen.

 

 

Option B. Uncrossed diplopia: Uncrossed diplopia occurs when images appear on the same side as the eye seeing them. It would involve seeing more dots (double vision) rather than missing a dot due to suppression.

 

 

Option D. LE suppression: Left eye suppression would result in the patient seeing only two red dots, as the left eye is not contributing to the vision. This does not match the observed scenario of seeing three green dots.

 

Educational Objective:


Seeing three green dots on the Worth 4-dot test indicates right eye suppression (RE suppression), as the right eye is not seeing the red dot.

questions.text: A 1-month-old baby presents with an olive-shaped mass and recurrent vomiting. An ultrasound (USG) was performed, as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) CHPS (Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis)

 
The correct diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS). This condition is characterized by hypertrophy of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction of the gastric outlet. Clinically, it often presents in infants around 3-6 weeks old with symptoms such as projectile vomiting (non-bilious), an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen, and visible peristalsis. The ultrasound image supports this diagnosis by showing a thickened pyloric muscle with measurements typically around 4 mm in thickness and 16 mm in length, which are diagnostic for CHPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intussusception: Intussusception is characterized by the telescoping of one segment of the intestine into another, leading to symptoms like colicky abdominal pain, a palpable abdominal mass, and “red currant jelly” stools (due to blood and mucus). It commonly presents with intermittent, severe abdominal pain and is typically not associated with a palpable olive-shaped mass or recurrent vomiting alone.

 

Option C. Meckel’s Diverticulum: Meckel’s Diverticulum is a congenital abnormality that results from an incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct. It may present with painless rectal bleeding, abdominal pain, or signs of intestinal obstruction. The appearance on imaging is different, and it is not associated with the olive-shaped mass or the characteristic pyloric muscle thickening seen in CHPS.

 

Educational Objective:


CHPS should be suspected in infants presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting, an olive-shaped abdominal mass, and confirmed with ultrasound showing pyloric muscle thickening and elongation (typically 4 mm thickness and 16 mm length)

questions.text: A study was undertaken to estimate the effect of a drug ‘D’ in three different groups – Plants, Animals, and Human beings. Samples were chosen randomly out of the three groups individually. This is a type of? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling is a sampling method where the total population is divided into homogeneous subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, and then random samples are taken from each stratum. In this question, the total population consists of three different groups: plants, animals, and humans, each forming a distinct stratum. After forming these strata, random sampling is conducted within each group to select samples, ensuring representation from all subgroups.

 

This approach ensures that the study includes balanced and proportional representation of each group, reflecting the actual composition of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random sampling: Simple random sampling involves selecting individuals purely by chance from the entire population without dividing it into subgroups. In this scenario, samples are taken from specific groups rather than randomly from the entire population.

 

Option B. Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting samples from a population at regular intervals (e.g., every nth member). This technique is not used here as the sampling is done within defined groups, not systematically across the whole population.

 

Option D. Cluster random sampling: In cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters (often geographically or by natural grouping), and entire clusters are randomly selected for study. In this question, the groups (plants, animals, humans) are not clusters but strata, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling involves dividing a heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups and then conducting random sampling within each subgroup.

choices.text: Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother.
Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.
Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G5L4 with all 4-girl children presents at 18 weeks and asks for the sex of the child on ultrasound. This is her first antenatal visit. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, don’t check the sex.


The Ans. is C because, according to the Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques (PCPNDT) Act, sex determination of the fetus is illegal and punishable by law. At 18 weeks, the primary purpose of the ultrasound is to assess gestational age and check for any fetal abnormalities as part of the anomaly scan. Checking or revealing the sex of the fetus is prohibited and carries legal consequences. Therefore, the healthcare provider should perform the ultrasound for the medical purposes it is intended for and avoid even viewing the sex of the fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex, and tell the mother: is incorrect because checking the sex and informing the mother is illegal under the PCPNDT Act, and can lead to legal repercussions, including imprisonment.

 

Option B. Do ultrasound for gestational age, check for abnormalities, check sex but don’t tell the mother: is also incorrect. Even looking at the fetus’s sex, regardless of whether it is disclosed, is a violation of the law and is punishable.

 

Option D. Don’t do ultrasound, do ANC only: is incorrect because the ultrasound at 18 weeks is necessary for evaluating gestational age and detecting any fetal abnormalities, which are critical aspects of prenatal care.

 

Educational Objective:


The key point to remember is that checking or revealing the sex of the fetus during an ultrasound is illegal under the PCPNDT Act. The ultrasound should only be used for assessing fetal gestational age and abnormalities.

questions.text: A male present with grouped painful vesicular lesions in the genital area. History of multiple sexual partners present. Irregular use of condoms history present. Smear showed MNGCs. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes genitalis

 

Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). The presentation of grouped painful vesicular lesions on an erythematous base in the genital area, especially in a patient with a history of multiple sexual partners and irregular condom use, is highly suggestive of herpes genitalis. The presence of multinucleated giant cells (MNGCs) on a smear is a key diagnostic feature of HSV infection. This is because HSV causes the fusion of infected cells, leading to the formation of these giant cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes zoster: Herpes zoster (shingles) typically presents as painful vesicular lesions following a dermatomal distribution, usually on one side of the body. The lesions do not cluster in the genital area unless the sacral nerve is involved, which is uncommon. Also, the absence of a dermatomal pattern makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Warts: Genital warts, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), present as painless, cauliflower-like growths rather than painful vesicular lesions. The description of painful lesions and the presence of MNGCs on the smear make this option unlikely.

 

Option D. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as a painful genital ulcer with ragged edges and undermined borders. It does not present with vesicular lesions or MNGCs on a smear, making this diagnosis incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes genitalis should be considered when a patient presents with grouped painful vesicular lesions in the genital area, especially when there is a history of risky sexual behavior and multinucleated giant cells are observed on a smear.

choices.text: Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.
Apoferritin is the storage form.
Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood.
Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

 

Iron metabolism involves complex processes where iron must be in the correct oxidation state to be absorbed and utilized effectively by the body. Iron in the diet is primarily found in the ferric (Fe3+) form, but for it to be absorbed across the apical membrane of enterocytes in the intestine, it needs to be converted into the ferrous (Fe2+) form. This conversion is crucial because only ferrous iron can be effectively transported into the cells. The statement in option A is incorrect because it suggests the opposite process—conversion from ferrous to ferric—before absorption, which is not accurate. The conversion actually goes from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) before iron is absorbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apoferritin is the storage form: This statement is correct. Apoferritin binds with iron to form ferritin, which is the storage form of iron within cells.

 

Option C. Iron is transported via transferrin in the blood: This is also correct. After iron is absorbed into the bloodstream, it binds to the protein transferrin, which transports it to various tissues, including the bone marrow for hemoglobin production.

 

Option D. Ascorbic acid helps in iron reabsorption: This statement is true. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) reduces ferric iron (Fe3+) to ferrous iron (Fe2+), which enhances its absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron must be converted from ferric (Fe3+) to ferrous (Fe2+) form for effective absorption through the apical membrane of enterocytes

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dL) and LDL 220 mg/dL were found to be raised. What is the defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LDL receptors defect

 

The patient's symptoms of multiple tendon xanthomas, elevated serum cholesterol, and high LDL levels indicate Type II hyperlipoproteinemia, commonly known as familial hypercholesterolemia. This condition is primarily caused by a defect in LDL receptors, leading to impaired clearance of LDL from the bloodstream. The resulting elevated LDL levels promote cholesterol deposition in tendons, forming xanthomas. Treatment typically focuses on reducing LDL cholesterol levels through diet, medication, or in severe cases, LDL apheresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: This defect leads to Type I hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by high levels of chylomicrons and triglycerides, but not elevated LDL or cholesterol. Symptoms typically include pancreatitis and eruptive xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Apo E defect: Apo E defect leads to Type III hyperlipoproteinemia, also known as dysbetalipoproteinemia. This condition is associated with elevated remnants of chylomicrons and VLDL, resulting in palmar xanthomas, not tendon xanthomas, and does not specifically cause the high LDL levels seen in this patient.

 

Option D. LCAT deficiency: LCAT deficiency affects HDL cholesterol conversion to cholesterol esters and does not directly affect LDL levels. It is associated with conditions such as Norum disease or fish eye disease, presenting with corneal opacity and hemolytic anemia rather than tendon xanthomas or elevated LDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDL receptor defects cause familial hypercholesterolemia, characterized by elevated LDL, cholesterol levels, and tendon xanthomas.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prader-Willi syndrome

 

The image represents chromosome 15, showing a deletion specifically on the paternal chromosome. Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by the deletion of a segment on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13.

 

This genetic disorder is characterized by hypotonia, poor feeding in infancy, hyperphagia leading to obesity in childhood, intellectual disability, and distinct physical features.

 

Prader-Willi syndrome can also occur due to maternal uniparental disomy (Maternal UPD), where two copies of the maternal chromosome are present, and no paternal copy is active.

 

These two mechanisms—paternal deletion and maternal uniparental disomy—are the main causes of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

In rare cases, an issue with imprinting itself can also lead to the syndrome, but the primary focus is on the two causes mentioned.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Angelman syndrome: Angelman syndrome is caused by a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of chromosome 15q11-q13 or by paternal uniparental disomy. It presents with severe intellectual disability, ataxia, seizures, and a characteristic happy demeanor with frequent smiling and laughter, which differs from Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option C. VHL syndrome: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with mutations on chromosome 3, leading to various tumors, including hemangioblastomas, renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas. It is unrelated to chromosome 15 deletions.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18) is a chromosomal disorder caused by an extra chromosome 18, presenting with severe intellectual disability, heart defects, and characteristic physical anomalies. It does not involve deletions on chromosome 15.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by maternal uniparental disomy, and is characterized by obesity due to hyperphagia, intellectual disability, and specific behavioral traits.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman whose last delivery was 5 years back presents with secondary amenorrhea of 2 years. She does not bleed on giving estrogen and progesterone. A laparoscopy shows the following. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital TB

 

The patient presents with secondary amenorrhea for two years and does not bleed when given estrogen and progesterone, indicating that the problem lies in the endometrium. The destruction of the endometrium can occur due to two main conditions: Asherman's syndrome and genital tuberculosis.

 

  • Asherman's syndrome involves intrauterine adhesions typically following a vigorous dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • Genital tuberculosis, however, causes chronic endometritis, leading to the destruction of the endometrium and the absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. The laparoscopy shows whitish caseating lesions on the surface of the uterus, which are characteristic of genital tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly causing pelvic pain and infertility. It does not typically result in secondary amenorrhea or the absence of bleeding on hormone administration, and it does not produce the characteristic whitish lesions seen in the laparoscopy.

 

Option B. Fibroids: Uterine fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus. They can cause menorrhagia, pelvic pressure, and pain but do not lead to secondary amenorrhea or absence of withdrawal bleeding upon hormone administration. Fibroids also do not present with caseating lesions.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that rarely affects the genital tract. It does not cause endometrial destruction, secondary amenorrhea, or the absence of withdrawal bleeding when given hormones, nor does it produce the characteristic uterine lesions seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis can cause chronic endometritis and endometrial destruction, leading to secondary amenorrhea and absence of withdrawal bleeding on hormone administration, with characteristic whitish caseating lesions visible on laparoscopy.

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

questions.text: 18-year-old female presented with high fever and pain in knee and ankle joints. On examination, the patient had a pan-systolic murmur at the apex. Rheumatoid factor is negative. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Rheumatic Fever

 

The presentation of high fever, joint pain (especially in the knee and ankle), and a pan-systolic murmur at the apex suggests mitral regurgitation, which is often seen in acute rheumatic fever. This condition is particularly common among younger individuals and fits within the Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever, which includes major criteria such as arthritis and carditis, and minor criteria like fever. In this case, the presence of carditis (evidenced by the murmur indicating mitral regurgitation) and arthritis confirms the diagnosis. Acute rheumatic fever commonly leads to valvular damage, primarily affecting the mitral valve, resulting in mitral regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Seronegative RA: This option is incorrect because seronegative rheumatoid arthritis is usually a chronic condition that does not present with acute fever or heart murmurs. The patient’s presentation does not fit the typical characteristics of seronegative RA.

 

Option C. Ankylosing spondylitis: This is incorrect as ankylosing spondylitis commonly affects the spine and sacroiliac joints and does not usually present with high fever, mitral regurgitation, or the acute onset seen in this case.

 

Option D. Septic arthritis: This is incorrect because, although septic arthritis can present with joint pain and fever, it would not explain the presence of a pan-systolic murmur or fulfill the criteria for carditis seen in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute rheumatic fever is diagnosed when a young patient presents with fever, migratory arthritis, and carditis, often leading to mitral valve involvement, characterized by a murmur indicative of mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

  

The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords, which allows for the production of higher frequency sounds. When the vocal cords are tightly stretched, they vibrate at a higher frequency, which is necessary for producing high-pitched notes.

 

In this scenario, the female singer is unable to sing higher frequency notes, indicating that her vocal cords are not adequately tense. This suggests paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which normally maintains the tension of the vocal cords. If the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed, typically due to damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, the vocal cords become bowed, loose, and floppy, impairing the ability to produce high-frequency sounds.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, which means it separates the vocal cords during breathing. It does not contribute to tensing the vocal cords for high-frequency sound production.

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as both an adductor and a relaxer of the vocal cords, contributing to lowering the pitch of the voice rather than raising it. It does not tense the vocal cords and, therefore, does not aid in the production of higher frequency notes.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle functions as an adductor, helping to bring the vocal cords together. It does not have a role in tensing the vocal cords for higher frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

questions.text: Which of these is used for immediate reversal of Vecuronium in a patient for normal kidney function? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent / cyclodextrin molecule used to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, particularly rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecule, thereby rendering it inactive and allowing for rapid reversal of muscle paralysis. Sugammadex is particularly advantageous in cases where quick recovery from neuromuscular blockade is required, and it is effective in patients with normal kidney function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used primarily to reverse the effects of anticholinergic toxicity. It is not used to reverse neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium.

 

Option C. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia. It has no role in reversing neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used to induce short-term paralysis, typically for intubation. It is not used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium; rather, it is itself a paralytic agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the drug of choice for the immediate reversal of vecuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: The given instrument is used for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Low air velocity

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Kata thermometer. The Kata thermometer was traditionally used to measure the cooling power of air. This measurement is based on how quickly the thermometer cools down when exposed to moving air, which directly correlates to the cooling effect of the air. However, its modern application is primarily focused on assessing low air velocity. It measures the rate of heat loss in still air, helping to determine the movement and speed of low-velocity air in environments such as controlled climates or specific laboratory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Air pollution: The Kata thermometer is not used to measure air pollution. Air pollution measurement typically involves devices that can detect particulate matter or specific pollutants, such as gas analyzers or particle counters.

 

Option B. Air humidity: Measuring air humidity is generally done using hygrometer. Hygrometers determine the amount of moisture in the air, which is unrelated to the cooling effect or air velocity measurement.

 

Option C. Cooling power of air: Although historically correct, this option is no longer the primary use of the Kata thermometer. The instrument was used in the past for this purpose, but it has evolved to mainly assess low air velocity, making this answer outdated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kata thermometer is primarily used today to assess low air velocity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of cervical erosion and spotting since 2 months. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  LBC + HPV + cervical biopsy


The patient is a 45-year-old woman presenting with cervical erosion and spotting, which raises a concern for potential cervical cancer. In such cases, the next best step involves a comprehensive approach to screen for cervical cancer:

 

  1. Liquid-based cytology (LBC): This test is used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  2. HPV testing: This helps identify high-risk human papillomavirus strains that are associated with cervical cancer.
  3. Cervical biopsy: If any abnormalities are found on cytology or HPV testing, a cervical biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Performing all three tests together provides a thorough evaluation, as cervical cancer screening is essential in women presenting with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pap smear + HCV: While a Pap smear is appropriate for screening, HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) testing is unrelated to the current presentation of cervical symptoms.

 

Option C. Pap smear + HBV: Similar to option B, the Pap smear is correct, but testing for HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) does not address the concern for cervical cancer.

 

Option D. VDRL + HBV: VDRL is used for syphilis screening and is not relevant to cervical erosion and spotting, nor is HBV testing in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


For a patient with cervical erosion and spotting, the best approach is to screen for cervical cancer with LBC, HPV testing, and a cervical biopsy if indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following cardioselective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisoprolol

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been clinically proven to reduce mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure (CHF). It works by decreasing the heart rate, reducing myocardial oxygen demand, and limiting the harmful effects of sympathetic nervous system activation in heart failure. Along with metoprolol and carvedilol, bisoprolol is one of the few beta-blockers approved for use in CHF due to its demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and improving patient outcomes.

 

Remember - Drugs that decrease mortality are primarily those that inhibit the renin-angiotensin pathway, including beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, ARBs (angiotensin II receptor blockers), and angiotensin receptor blockers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not typically used in the management of CHF due to its lack of cardioselectivity. It has not been shown to decrease mortality in patients with CHF.

 

Option C. Labetalol: Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional alpha-blocking properties. While it is useful in the management of hypertensive emergencies, it is not used for chronic management of CHF and has not been shown to decrease mortality in these patients.

 

Option D. Pindolol: Pindolol is another non-selective beta-blocker with intrinsic sympathomimetic activity (ISA). It is not suitable for CHF management and does not have evidence supporting a mortality benefit in heart failure patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisoprolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker that has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with chronic congestive heart failure.

questions.text: Identify the level of amputation: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Below Knee

 

The correct answer is Below Knee amputation. In the provided image, the amputation level shows both the tibia and fibula bones, indicating that the amputation is below the knee. A below knee amputation preserves the knee joint, which is crucial for improved mobility and prosthetic fitting compared to an above knee amputation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Above Knee: In an above knee amputation, only the femur would be visible as the amputation occurs above the knee joint, which is not the case in the image provided.

 

Option C. Lis Franc: A Lis Franc amputation is a type of foot amputation that involves the tarsometatarsal joints.

 

Option D. Chopart: A Chopart amputation involves a disarticulation through the midfoot, specifically at the talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints. The image does not show the foot structures required for a Chopart amputation, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a below knee amputation, both the tibia and fibula bones are visible, distinguishing it from above knee and foot-level amputations like Lis Franc and Chopart.

questions.text: Image of a patient with large ulcerated breast cancer with liver metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple mastectomy

 

The patient in the image has a large ulcerated breast tumor with confirmed liver metastasis, classifying the cancer as stage IV (T4, M1). In cases of stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, the primary goal of management shifts from curative to palliative care, focusing on improving quality of life and managing symptoms.

For patients with large ulcerated tumors, palliative simple mastectomy may be considered to alleviate symptoms like pain, ulceration, discharge, or infection, which can significantly impact the patient’s quality of life. This procedure is not intended to cure but to provide local control of the tumor and improve comfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy): This is a more aggressive surgical approach that involves removal of the breast tissue along with axillary lymph nodes. It is typically reserved for curative intent in earlier stages of breast cancer without distant metastasis. It is not appropriate for palliation in stage IV disease with liver metastasis.

 

Option C. Radical mastectomy: This involves removal of the entire breast, underlying chest muscles, and axillary lymph nodes. This extensive procedure is rarely performed today and is not suitable for palliative care in metastatic disease due to its high morbidity without a survival benefit.

 

Option D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is used in locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) to shrink tumors before surgery, but in the presence of distant metastasis (M1), systemic chemotherapy alone would be preferred for palliative purposes. Surgery would only follow if there was a significant symptomatic tumor burden requiring local control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with stage IV breast cancer with distant metastasis, such as liver metastasis, the primary focus is on palliation. Simple mastectomy may be performed to manage symptoms from a large ulcerated tumor, but more extensive surgeries or curative approaches are not indicated.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD developed breathlessness and is on mechanical ventilation. He suddenly developed hypoxia, and on examination, he has reduced/absent breath sounds on the left hemithorax with increased peak inspiratory pressure. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pneumothorax

 

Pneumothorax is a common complication in ICU patients, particularly those on mechanical ventilation. It is often caused by barotrauma, which can lead to an acute deterioration in ventilated patients, presenting with sudden hypoxemia and increased peak inspiratory pressure (PIP). The clinical signs of absent or reduced breath sounds on one side strongly indicate pneumothorax. In such cases, increased PIP is due to the poor lung compliance caused by air in the pleural space, compromising the lung's ability to expand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Exacerbation: Acute exacerbation of COPD usually presents with worsening dyspnea, increased sputum production, or change in sputum color, not sudden absence of breath sounds on one side. There is no specific mention of plateau pressure changes that would suggest this diagnosis, making it unlikely in this context.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism generally causes hypoxia and sudden respiratory distress but does not specifically lead to absent breath sounds on one side or increased PIP. Instead, PIP would typically remain normal, as it is an extrapulmonary cause of respiratory deterioration.

 

Option D. Pneumonia: Pneumonia could present with hypoxia but is usually associated with bronchial breath sounds or signs of consolidation rather than absent breath sounds on one side. The examination findings and increased PIP make pneumonia an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumothorax should be considered in ventilated patients with sudden respiratory deterioration, absent breath sounds on one side, and increased peak inspiratory pressure.

questions.text:
HDI is calculated by using ? [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Life expectancy at birth
  2. Mean years of schooling
  3. Gross national product
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) All three


The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite index used to measure the overall achievement of a country in three basic dimensions of human development:

 

  1. Health: Measured by life expectancy at birth, which reflects the average number of years a newborn is expected to live if current mortality rates continue to apply.
  2. Education: Measured by the mean years of schooling for adults aged 25 years or older and expected years of schooling for children entering school. This represent knowledge, enrolment ratio.
  3. Living Standards: Measured by Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, expressed in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP) in US dollars.

 

These components together provide a summary measure of average achievement in key dimensions of human development, allowing for comparisons across countries.

 

Educational Objective:
 

HDI is calculated using three components: life expectancy at birth, mean years of schooling, and Gross National Income per capita. These factors represent health, education, and living standards, respectively.

 

  • HDI range – 0 to +1
  • HDI (India) – 0.644 (Rank 134)
  • HDI (Switzerland) – 0.96 (Rank 1)

questions.text: A patient presents with headaches, confusion, and has recently been diagnosed with a brain tumor. MRI of the brain revealed a cerebellar mass. The family history reveals occurrences of both brain and kidney tumors. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome


Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an inherited disorder characterized by the development of multiple tumors and cysts in different parts of the body. This syndrome is strongly associated with cerebellar hemangioblastomas (a type of brain tumor) and renal cell carcinoma (RCC), among other types of tumors. The clinical presentation of a cerebellar mass along with a family history of both brain and kidney tumors is highly suggestive of VHL syndrome. The presence of these tumors in a familial pattern fits the diagnostic criteria for VHL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis: This genetic condition often presents with nerve sheath tumors (neurofibromas), optic gliomas, and café-au-lait spots but does not typically involve both cerebellar tumors and kidney tumors such as RCC.

 

Option B. Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni is associated with a variety of cancers, including brain tumors, sarcomas, and breast cancer, due to TP53 mutations. However, it does not specifically link cerebellar and kidney tumors as seen in VHL.

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: This condition is characterized by benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain (subependymal giant cell astrocytomas) and kidneys (angiomyolipomas). However, it does not fit the combination of cerebellar tumors and RCC typical of VHL syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:


Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome is associated with cerebellar hemangioblastomas and renal cell carcinoma, especially in the context of familial occurrences. Recognizing the combination of brain and kidney tumors should prompt consideration of VHL.

choices.text: Penectomy with bilateral superficial inguinal dissection

questions.text: A Patient presented with a growth on the penis, which was diagnosed as a T3 cancer without lymph node metastasis. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penectomy with bilateral ilio-inguinal dissection

 

In the case of T3 penile cancer, the tumor has invaded the corpus cavernosum, indicating an advanced stage of the disease. The management of such advanced penile cancer requires aggressive treatment to control both the primary tumor and the potential spread to lymph nodes.

 

The recommended approach includes penectomy to remove the primary tumor and ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection as a prophylactic measure. This is because, even though there are no clinically detectable lymph node metastases (N0), the risk of micro-metastasis is significant in T3 cancers. Ilio-inguinal dissection encompasses both superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes and provides comprehensive regional control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penectomy: While penectomy addresses the primary tumor, it does not manage the risk of lymphatic spread, which is critical in advanced stages like T3. This option alone is insufficient for comprehensive cancer management.

 

Option B. Penectomy with superficial inguinal dissection: Superficial inguinal dissection alone is outdated and considered inadequate, as it does not address the deeper lymph nodes where metastasis may occur. Current guidelines favor a more extensive approach, including both superficial and deep nodes.

 

Option D. Penectomy with orchidectomy: Orchidectomy is not a part of the standard management for penile cancer, as it involves the removal of the testes and is relevant in testicular cancer, not penile cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For T3 penile cancer without lymph node metastasis, the standard management is penectomy along with ilio-inguinal lymph node dissection to address both the primary tumor and potential regional spread.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling and undergoes a tissue biopsy which reveals the cells as shown in the image. Which of the following is the likely gene affected in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BRAF gene

 

The biopsy image shows cells with optically clear cytoplasm, which is characteristic of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC).

 

This type of cancer is often associated with mutations in the BRAF gene, particularly in the aggressive tall cell variant of PTC.

 

BRAF mutations, specifically the BRAF V600E mutation, are frequently found in these tumors and are associated with a more aggressive disease course and extra-thyroidal extension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RET gene: The RET gene mutation is commonly associated with Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC) rather than Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma. It is not the gene affected in this case, as the histological findings are not consistent with MTC.

 

Option B. RAS gene: RAS gene mutations are typically associated with Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma rather than Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma. Follicular thyroid cancers have a different appearance and do not show the clear cytoplasm seen here.

 

Option D. P53 gene: P53 mutations are commonly associated with Anaplastic Thyroid Carcinoma, which is a much more aggressive and undifferentiated cancer. The histological features of anaplastic carcinoma differ significantly from the clear cells seen in papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma often presents with cells that have optically clear cytoplasm, and this type of cancer is frequently associated with BRAF gene mutations, especially in the tall cell variant which is more aggressive.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presenting with recurrent respiratory infections. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CPAM


Congenital Pulmonary Airway Malformation (CPAM) is a congenital lung lesion characterized by multiple cystic spaces within the lungs, often detected through imaging such as CT or X-rays. In this case, the child’s imaging shows a multi-cystic, bubbly appearance with air-filled spaces, which is typical of CPAM. CPAM often presents with recurrent respiratory infections due to the abnormal lung structure. Although the images combine antenatal ultrasound and postnatal imaging, they highlight the congenital nature of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyopneumothorax: This condition involves pus and air within the pleural cavity, usually caused by infection or trauma. It presents with an air-fluid level, often with signs of pleural infection such as fever and chest pain. The multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging does not match this condition.

 

Option C. CDH (Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia): CDH involves the herniation of abdominal contents into the thoracic cavity, usually on the left side. CDH presents with bowel loops in the chest and displacement of the lung tissue, which is not observed here. The appearance of the lesion on the right side with multiple air-filled cysts rules out CDH.

 

Option D. Lung abscess: A lung abscess is a localized area of necrosis and pus within the lung, often appearing as a round lesion with an air-fluid level. This differs significantly from the bubbly, multi-cystic appearance seen in the imaging, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


CPAM is characterized by multiple cystic, air-filled spaces in the lung and is a congenital lesion that often presents with recurrent respiratory infections.

questions.text: What would be the mode of delivery in images 1 and 2? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Image 1: Vaginal; image 2: Cesarean

 

In the provided images, the presentation of the twins is crucial in determining the mode of delivery:

 

  • Image 1: Both twins are in a cephalic presentation (head down), making it safe to consider vaginal delivery. Twin pregnancies where both twins present cephalically are usually managed vaginally unless there are other contraindications.
  • Image 2: The first twin (Twin A or the lowermost baby) is in a breech presentation, while the second twin is cephalic. In this scenario, a cesarean section is preferred to avoid complications associated with breech delivery, such as cord prolapse or head entrapment. Therefore, cesarean delivery is the recommended mode for this presentation.

 

Indications for cesarean in twin pregnancy:

 

  1. First twin is non-cephalic (breech or transverse presentation).
  2. Monochorionic, monoamniotic twins: Elective LSCS at around 34 weeks.
  3. Conjoined twins.
  4. Higher-order multiples (triplets, quadruplets, or more).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In twin pregnancies, the mode of delivery is determined primarily by the presentation of the first twin. If the first twin is cephalic, vaginal delivery can be considered, but if the first twin is non-cephalic (e.g., breech), a cesarean section is generally recommended.

questions.text: Giving TPN (total para-enteral nutrition) in a patient in ICU with metabolic syndrome predisposes to: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia


Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) in a patient with metabolic syndrome predisposes to hyperglycemia. Metabolic syndrome is characterized by insulin resistance, often seen in conditions such as type 2 diabetes, obesity, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and, in some cases, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Insulin resistance impairs the body’s ability to utilize glucose efficiently. When TPN, which is high in glucose, is administered, the already compromised insulin response leads to elevated blood glucose levels, resulting in hyperglycemia. This is a common complication in patients receiving TPN, especially those with underlying metabolic conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reactive Hypoglycemia: Reactive hypoglycemia is a condition where blood glucose levels drop excessively after eating, due to an overproduction of insulin. It is not typically associated with TPN or metabolic syndrome, as TPN administration generally leads to hyperglycemia rather than hypoglycemia due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. Hyperlipidemia: While hyperlipidemia is a component of metabolic syndrome, it is not a direct complication specifically associated with TPN. Although TPN can contain lipids, its primary complication related to metabolic syndrome is hyperglycemia due to glucose intolerance.

 

Option D. Hyperuricemia: Hyperuricemia, characterized by elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, can be associated with metabolic syndrome but is not directly induced by TPN administration. The primary metabolic disturbance from TPN in these patients is related to glucose management rather than uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In patients with metabolic syndrome, TPN can exacerbate hyperglycemia due to pre-existing insulin resistance. This underscores the need for careful monitoring of blood glucose levels and management of insulin requirements in these patients.

choices.text: A – Apocrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Arrector pilorum, B – Apocrine sweat gland, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Sebaceous gland, B – Eccrine sweat gland, C – Arrector pilorum, D – Apocrine sweat gland
A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the skin appendages labeled A to D in the given histological image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

 

In the image provided, several distinct structures of the skin are labeled:

 

A (Eccrine sweat gland): Eccrine sweat glands are small, coiled glands located superficially in the dermis. They are responsible for temperature regulation through sweat secretion. In the image, A is identified as the eccrine sweat gland, which appears closer to the skin surface compared to the apocrine gland.

 

B (Arrector pilorum): This is a small muscle attached to the hair follicle known as the arrector pilorum. It is responsible for causing hair to stand up during cold or emotional stress, leading to goosebumps.

 

C (Sebaceous gland): These glands are associated with hair follicles and secrete sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. In the image, C is correctly identified as the sebaceous gland.

 

D (Apocrine sweat gland): Apocrine sweat glands are located deeper in the dermis or hypodermis and are associated with hair follicles. They produce a thicker, milky secretion that contributes to body odor when broken down by bacteria. D is correctly labeled as the apocrine sweat gland, which is found deeper compared to eccrine glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eccrine sweat glands are located closer to the skin surface, arrector pilorum is a small muscle connected to hair follicles, sebaceous glands produce sebum and are linked to hair follicles, while apocrine sweat glands are deeper and secrete a thicker fluid associated with hair follicles.

choices.text: Bath the baby with warm water immediately

questions.text: A mother delivers a 2.5 kg baby with normal vaginal delivery in a rural area. Which of the following is an incorrect statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bath the baby with warm water immediately

     

Newborn care practices emphasize immediate and appropriate actions to ensure the health and safety of the infant. Bathing the baby immediately after birth is discouraged because the baby's skin needs to adapt to the new environment, and the vernix (a protective layer on the skin) should be allowed to remain on the skin for as long as possible to provide a barrier against infection. Immediate bathing can lead to hypothermia and is generally not recommended, especially in settings where environmental conditions (such as warmth and cleanliness) are not optimal.

 

The recommended practice is to wait at least 24 hours and then start with gentle sponging until the umbilical cord falls off, typically within the first week of life. Only after this can full baths be introduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exclusive breastfeeding: This is the recommended feeding method for newborns, providing optimal nutrition and immunity support. It should be started within the first hour of birth.

 

Option C. Clean the eyes: Cleaning the eyes is a standard neonatal practice to prevent infection. This is part of routine newborn care and helps prevent neonatal conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact: Skin-to-skin contact is encouraged immediately after birth as it helps regulate the newborn's body temperature, promotes bonding, and supports breastfeeding initiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bathing a newborn immediately after birth is not recommended; it should be delayed until the umbilical cord falls off, and gentle sponging should be started after 24 hours to maintain hygiene and prevent hypothermia.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

 

 

The marked part in the image is the grounding electrode, also known as the reference electrode. In a cochlear implant, the grounding electrode is usually implanted in the temporalis area. Its primary function is to serve as a reference point for electrical signals, ensuring accurate signal transmission and reducing noise interference during the processing of sound signals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amplifier: An amplifier is not a distinct part of the cochlear implant. Instead, the sound processor amplifies and processes the sound signals before transmitting them to the receiver.

 

Option C. Receiver: The receiver in a cochlear implant is a component that lies under the skin and receives sound signals from the external transmitter. It is not the marked part in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: The electrode array is implanted inside the cochlea and is responsible for stimulating the auditory nerve. It directly interacts with the cochlea, unlike the grounding electrode that is positioned externally or at a different implant site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presented with weakness and fatigue. His BP was 80/60 mm Hg and his reports showed a serum Na+ of 127 mEq/L and serum K+ of 5.2 mEq/L. On examination, the patient had hyperpigmentation in the knuckles, arms, and legs. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary adrenal insufficiency

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency, also known as Addison's disease, is characterized by inadequate production of adrenal hormones such as cortisol and aldosterone. The clinical presentation typically includes fatigue, weakness, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalances such as hyponatremia (low sodium) and hyperkalemia (high potassium). The physical finding of hyperpigmentation, especially in areas like the knuckles, arms, and legs, is a classic feature due to increased production of ACTH, which has melanocyte-stimulating activity.

 

In this case, the combination of fatigue, hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation strongly supports the diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency. The presence of these symptoms is almost pathognomonic for Addison's disease, especially when associated with a history of chronic fatigue and weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conns syndrome: Conn's syndrome, or primary hyperaldosteronism, typically presents with hypertension (high blood pressure) and hypokalemia (low potassium), not hypotension and hyperkalemia. Thus, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency can cause hyperpigmentation, it does not present with the electrolyte abnormalities seen here (hyponatremia and hyperkalemia) or the profound hypotension. The presentation in this case does not align with B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion): SIADH can cause hyponatremia, but it is associated with euvolemia or hypervolemia, not the hypotension, hypovolemia, and hyperkalemia seen in this patient. The presence of hyperkalemia is not typical of SIADH, ruling out this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) presents with hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hyperpigmentation due to low cortisol and aldosterone levels.

questions.text: What is the best test to diagnose Wilson’s disease? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatic copper estimation

 

Wilson’s disease is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other tissues, leading to hepato-lenticular degeneration. The most definitive and gold standard diagnostic test for Wilson’s disease is hepatic copper estimation, typically performed through a liver biopsy. This test directly measures the copper content in liver tissue, confirming the disease's diagnosis.

 

In addition, the Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a copper deposit around the cornea, is a commonly seen ophthalmic feature of the disease. Another important ophthalmologic finding in Wilson's disease is the sunflower cataract, which occurs in the lens. These signs are crucial for diagnosing the hepato-lenticular degeneration associated with Wilson's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine copper: This test measures the amount of copper excreted in the urine, which can be elevated in Wilson’s disease but is not definitive for diagnosis. It is often used to monitor treatment response rather than as a primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option B. Serum ceruloplasmin: Wilson’s disease is associated with low levels of ceruloplasmin, a copper-carrying protein. However, low ceruloplasmin levels alone are not specific to Wilson’s disease and can be seen in other conditions, making it a supportive but not definitive test.

 

Option C. Serum copper: Although serum copper levels may be low in Wilson’s disease due to decreased ceruloplasmin, free serum copper may be elevated. This test is not reliable for diagnosing Wilson’s disease and is better used as part of a comprehensive evaluation.

 

Educational Objective:


Hepatic copper estimation via liver biopsy is the gold standard test for diagnosing Wilson’s disease, providing a direct measure of copper accumulation in the liver.

questions.text: Injury to which nerve results in absent gag reflex? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX & X

 

The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is a protective mechanism that prevents foreign objects from entering the throat. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components:

 

  • Sensory Component (Afferent): The sensory part of the gag reflex is mediated by the Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX). When the posterior wall of the pharynx or the palate is touched, the sensory information is carried by the Glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla oblongata.
  • Motor Component (Efferent): The motor response, which causes the contraction of the pharyngeal muscles, is mediated by the Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X). This nerve provides the efferent pathway, leading to the muscle contraction observed in the gag reflex.

 

Injury to either of these nerves can disrupt the reflex: damage to CN IX affects the sensory input, while damage to CN X affects the motor response, resulting in an absent gag reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (VII & X): Cranial Nerve VII (Facial nerve) is not involved in the gag reflex. The Facial nerve primarily controls muscles of facial expression and does not play a role in the sensory or motor aspects of the gag reflex.

 

Option C (V & IX): Cranial Nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing, not for the gag reflex. Therefore, its involvement in the gag reflex is incorrect.

 

Option D (VII & IX): While Cranial Nerve IX is correctly identified as part of the reflex, Cranial Nerve VII is not involved. This makes the pairing incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
