The gag reflex involves the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for sensory input and the Vagus nerve (CN X) for motor response. Damage to either nerve can result in an absent gag reflex.

questions.text: Identify the blocked structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

The image shows a coronal CT scan of the sinuses, where a blocked structure is indicated by the arrow. The blockage appears to be in the maxillary sinus, which is characterized by the presence of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity, typically passing through the middle meatus. In this case, the blockage is in the maxillary sinus, as evidenced by the extension of the polyp towards the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinus: This is incorrect because the ethmoid sinus is located medially and superiorly to the maxillary sinus and does not match the position of the blockage shown in the image.

  

Option C. Frontal sinus: This is incorrect as the frontal sinus is located above the eyes and towards the forehead, which is not indicated as blocked in the image.

 Option D. Sphenoid sinus: This is incorrect because the sphenoid sinus is located deeper within the skull, behind the ethmoid sinuses, and is not the blocked area shown.

    

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary sinus can be blocked by an antrochoanal polyp that extends into the nasal cavity through the middle meatus.

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim was examined in court "in camera." What does it imply? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed proceeding

 

"In camera" is a legal term used to describe a judicial proceeding that is held privately, away from the public and the media. This setting is particularly used in sensitive cases, such as those involving sexual assault, to protect the privacy and dignity of the victim. In such proceedings, only selected individuals, such as the judge, lawyers, the accused, the victim, and sometimes a few relatives of the victim, are allowed to be present.

 

This type of trial is mandated in India for all sexual assault cases to ensure the victim's confidentiality and provide a safe environment free from public scrutiny. It is not a public trial, and the general public is not allowed to attend.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open proceeding: An open proceeding is accessible to the public and media, which is not suitable for sensitive cases like sexual assault due to privacy concerns. This option is incorrect because "in camera" specifically denotes a closed proceeding.

 

Option C. Recorded in camera: This option might seem correct due to the term "camera," but it does not mean the proceedings are being recorded. "In camera" refers to the closed nature of the trial, not to any form of recording.

 

Option D. Proceedings in another place: This option incorrectly implies that the trial is conducted at a different location. However, "in camera" refers to the nature of the trial being private, not about the location of the proceedings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"In camera" refers to a closed proceeding in court where only selected individuals are allowed to be present, ensuring the privacy of sensitive cases such as those involving sexual assault.

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Up to 48 hours

 

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) insertion timing can be categorized into three main periods:

 

  1. During Menstruation: IUCD insertion during menstruation is preferred within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to ensure the woman is not pregnant and to ease insertion due to the open cervical os.
  2. Immediate Postpartum: The best time for postpartum IUCD insertion is within the first 48 hours after delivery. If not done within this window, insertion can be performed up to 1 week postpartum. This timing is optimal as the cervix is dilated, and there is a reduced risk of expulsion compared to later periods.
  3. Post Puerperal: If IUCD insertion is not performed immediately postpartum, the next preferred timing is 6 to 8 weeks after delivery when the uterus has involuted and stabilized.

 

For this question, since the woman has just delivered, the most precise and preferred time is within the first 48 hours postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and chronic cough. He also mentions that he has had several ear infections and episodes of pneumonia over the past few years. On physical examination, you note digital clubbing. A chest X-ray is obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

Kartagener syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the triad of situs inversus (reversal of internal organs), chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis. The presence of dextrocardia  and the fundic gas bubble on the right side of the abdomen in the chest X-ray strongly suggest situs inversus. The patient's history of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and chronic cough further supports the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the lungs and digestive system. While it can cause recurrent respiratory infections, it is not associated with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. DiGeorge syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the development of several body systems, including the immune system and the heart. It is not associated with situs inversus, bronchiectasis, or chronic sinusitis.  

 

Option D. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. It is not associated with situs inversus, bronchiectasis, or chronic sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by the triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Anencephaly

 

The ultrasound image shows the absence of cranial bones, which are typically visible as white structures on ultrasound. In anencephaly, the forebrain and cranial vault are absent, resulting in a recognizable appearance on ultrasound. Additionally, anencephaly is often associated with prominent eyeballs, known as the "frog eye sign," further supporting this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: This condition presents as a fluid-filled cystic mass, often seen in the neck region. On ultrasound, cystic hygroma appears as a black (anechoic) structure due to its fluid content, which is not seen in this case.

 

Option C. Encephalocele: Encephalocele is characterized by herniation of brain tissue through a defect in the skull, usually seen as a sac-like protrusion. This appearance is distinct from anencephaly and involves brain tissue extending outside the cranial cavity, which is not observed here.

 

Option D. Dandy Walker malformation: This condition involves an enlarged posterior fossa with a cystic structure, indicating the presence of a posterior fossa cyst. The ultrasound findings of Dandy Walker malformation are distinct and do not match the current image showing an absence of cranial bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is diagnosed by the absence of cranial bones and brain tissue on ultrasound, often accompanied by the "frog eye sign."

questions.text: A patient presents with gradual loss of night vision and peripheral vision. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these symptoms according to the given fundoscopic image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinitis Pigmentosa

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is a progressive eye disease characterized by the loss of night vision (nyctalopia) and peripheral vision, often described as "tunnel vision." The disease involves the degeneration of photoreceptor cells in the retina, primarily affecting the rods, which are responsible for low-light vision.

 

The characteristic fundoscopic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa include:

 

  1. Black pigmentary deposits (bone spicule appearance) – These are seen around the periphery of the retina.
  2. Vascular attenuation – Retinal vessels are thinned out, indicating decreased blood flow.
  3. Waxy pallor of the optic disc – This is a pale appearance of the optic disc due to retinal degeneration.

 

The fundoscopic image shows black pigmentation and attenuated vessels, which are classic findings in Retinitis Pigmentosa, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fundus flavimaculatus: This condition is a variant of Stargardt disease and primarily involves the macula, showing yellowish flecks in the retina. This condition is associated with chromosome 1 and mutations in the ABCA4 gene.

 

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhage: Retinal hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the retina, often appearing as red patches or dots. It does not cause a gradual loss of night vision or tunnel vision and is not associated with black pigmentary changes.

 

 

Option D. Fundus Albipunctatus: This condition is characterized by white, dot-like lesions scattered across the retina and may also present with night vision problems. However, it lacks the black pigmentation and vascular attenuation seen in Retinitis Pigmentosa, making it an incorrect choice.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa is identified by a triad of symptoms: black pigmentary deposits, vascular attenuation, and waxy pallor of the optic disc, accompanied by nyctalopia and tunnel vision.

questions.text: Which artery is used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis and is present behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendon calcaneus? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior tibial artery

 

The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used in arteriovenous (AV) shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis access. This artery runs in the posterior compartment of the leg and is palpable behind the medial malleolus, approximately 2.5 cm anterior to the tendon calcaneus (Achilles tendon). It is a reliable location for vascular access because of its relatively superficial position and ease of palpation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peroneal artery: The peroneal artery is located in the lateral compartment of the leg and does not course near the medial malleolus, making it unsuitable for the AV shunting procedure described in the question.

 

Option B. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery is located on the anterior aspect of the leg and passes between the medial and lateral malleoli, where it is palpable in front of the ankle joint. It is not positioned behind the medial malleolus, hence it is not the correct answer.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is palpable on the dorsum of the foot near the navicular bone or intermediate cuneiform, far from the medial malleolus and tendon calcaneus. Therefore, it is not used for AV shunting as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery is the artery located behind the medial malleolus and is commonly used for AV shunting with the great saphenous vein in procedures like hemodialysis access due to its superficial location and ease of access.

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: A woman at 8 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propylthiouracil

 

During pregnancy, the treatment of hyperthyroidism, especially in the first trimester, requires careful consideration due to the potential teratogenic effects of antithyroid drugs.

 

  1. First Trimester Use of Propylthiouracil (PTU): Propylthiouracil is the preferred antithyroid medication during the first trimester of pregnancy because it has a lower risk of causing congenital anomalies compared to methimazole and carbimazole. PTU is recommended to minimize the potential for teratogenic effects that are particularly associated with methimazole during early pregnancy.
  2. Transition in Later Trimesters: In the second and third trimesters, the risk of liver toxicity with PTU increases, so it is common practice to switch back to methimazole or carbimazole as they are more effective and pose less hepatic risk compared to PTU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Methimazole is generally avoided in the first trimester due to its association with congenital abnormalities, particularly aplasia cutis (a scalp defect) and choanal atresia. It is considered safer in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is converted to methimazole in the body and shares the same risks during the first trimester, hence it is not recommended during early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine: This treatment is absolutely contraindicated during pregnancy at any stage as it can destroy fetal thyroid tissue and lead to fetal hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism due to its lower teratogenic risk compared to other antithyroid drugs.

questions.text: A patient is being treated with phenobarbitone. Which of the following is inhibited? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex I → coenzyme Q


Phenobarbitone is known to affect the electron transport chain, specifically inhibiting the transfer of electrons from Complex I to coenzyme Q. Complex I, also known as NADH dehydrogenase and NADH CoQ oxidoreductase, takes hydrogen from NADH and transfers electrons to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone). This step is crucial in the electron transport chain as it initiates the flow of electrons, which is essential for ATP production. Phenobarbitone inhibits this specific step, disrupting the electron flow, which impairs cellular energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complex II → coenzyme Q: This step involves the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, a different pathway not directly affected by phenobarbitone.

 

Option C. Complex III → Cyt. C: This step transfers electrons from coenzyme Q to cytochrome C, an independent part of the electron transport chain not impacted by phenobarbitone.

 

Option D. Complex IV → oxygen: This final step involves the transfer of electrons to oxygen, forming water. Phenobarbitone does not inhibit this part of the chain.

 

Educational Objective:


Phenobarbitone specifically inhibits the electron transport between Complex I and coenzyme Q, disrupting ATP production.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male came with complaints of asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions and hair loss as given below. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

The patient presents with several key clinical features: asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on the trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions (condyloma lata), and patchy hair loss. The patchy hair loss, described as "moth-eaten alopecia," is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. These signs are strongly indicative of an infection caused by Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis. The presence of condyloma lata and the specific type of alopecia observed are classical clues pointing towards this diagnosis.

 

DD of Patchy Alopecia – Alopecia areata, Tinea capitis, Trichotillomania, and Secondary Syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malassezia furfur: This organism is associated with conditions like pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, neither of which typically present with the described combination of symptoms, particularly the moth-eaten alopecia and condyloma lata.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus can cause skin infections and folliculitis, it does not typically cause the type of patchy alopecia or the other systemic symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Microsporum canis: This is a dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis, which can lead to patchy hair loss. However, tinea capitis would be associated with scaly patches and other signs of fungal infection rather than the systemic features like condyloma lata seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "moth-eaten alopecia" is a key diagnostic feature of secondary syphilis, and Treponema pallidum is the causative organism.

questions.text: A newborn presents with the condition shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital anomaly where the bladder is exposed outside the body. It presents as a defect in the lower abdominal wall, with the bladder mucosa visible. Characteristic features include a bifid scrotum, abnormal genitalia (bifid penis or clitoris), and exposure of the bladder trigone. The condition is often associated with other malformations, such as a wide pubic symphysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical hernia: This condition involves protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect at the umbilicus but remains covered by skin. It does not expose the bladder.

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: This defect occurs lateral to the umbilicus, commonly on the right, with the intestines protruding outside the abdomen without a protective membrane. The defect does not involve the bladder.

 

Option D. Omphalocele: This condition is characterized by herniation of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a thin membrane. Unlike bladder exstrophy, the organs are covered, and the defect involves the umbilical ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition where the bladder is exposed outside the abdomen, often accompanied by genital and pelvic abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for maintenance therapy in opioid abuse? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buprenorphine

 

Maintenance therapy in opioid dependence involves the use of long-acting opioids to stabilize the patient and prevent withdrawal symptoms, thus helping them gradually reduce dependency on more harmful opioids.

 

Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist that binds to the same receptors as other opioids but with a lower intrinsic activity, meaning it produces less euphoria and has a ceiling effect that reduces the risk of misuse. Additionally, buprenorphine has a long half-life, which makes it suitable for maintenance therapy as it allows for once-daily dosing and reduces withdrawal symptoms.

 

Another common medication used for maintenance therapy is methadone, a full opioid agonist. However, buprenorphine is often preferred due to its safety profile, particularly the lower risk of overdose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to manage symptoms of opioid withdrawal, particularly by reducing sympathetic overactivity (e.g., sweating, agitation, and anxiety). However, it is not used for maintenance therapy but rather for symptom control during detoxification.

 

Option C. Butorphanol: Butorphanol is an opioid analgesic that can be used for pain management. It is not typically used for maintenance therapy in opioid addiction and has potential for misuse.

 

Option D. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose. It does not have a role in maintenance therapy but is crucial for emergency management of opioid toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methadone and buprenorphine are long-acting opioids used for maintenance therapy in opioid addiction. They replace the addictive opioid to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • To treat withdrawal symptoms:
    • Diazepam (a benzodiazepine) is used for seizures.
    • Clonidine or beta blockers are used for sympathetic symptoms.
  • Naltrexone is used to prevent relapse in opioid addiction.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of aprepitant? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NK1 antagonist


Aprepitant is a Neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of substance P, a neuropeptide associated with the emesis reflex. It is primarily used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), especially in patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents like cisplatin. By inhibiting NK1 receptors in the brain, aprepitant effectively reduces the incidence of nausea and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:


Aprepitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist used in preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting by blocking the action of substance P.

questions.text: An athlete collapsed suddenly and dies. He had an abnormal septal thickening. His sibling also expired due to a cardiac condition earlier. His cardiac biopsy image is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

 

The clinical history and biopsy findings point towards hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). This condition is characterized by abnormal thickening of the heart's septum, often leading to asymmetrical hypertrophy that obstructs blood flow.

 

The cardiac biopsy image shows a characteristic "helter-skelter" or disorganized arrangement of cardiac muscle fibers, a hallmark of HCM.

 

The sudden death in an athlete and a family history of similar cardiac events strongly support this diagnosis, as HCM is often associated with sudden cardiac death during exertion due to outflow obstruction and arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: This condition involves normal-sized ventricles with rigid, stiff heart walls, leading to impaired diastolic filling. It does not present with significant septal hypertrophy, or a disorganized fiber arrangement seen in HCM.

 

Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy: In this condition, the heart chambers are dilated and the heart muscle is weakened, leading to systolic dysfunction. It does not involve septal thickening or the characteristic histological findings of HCM.

 

Option D. Cardiac tumor/myocarditis: These conditions would present differently, often with symptoms related to inflammation or mass effect rather than sudden death associated with septal hypertrophy and disordered muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by asymmetrical septal hypertrophy, disorganized cardiac muscle fibers, and is commonly associated with sudden death in young athletes, particularly during exertion.

choices.text: Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse
Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins
Continue CPR till pulse is back

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is undergoing CPR. He is pulseless and shows the below ECG. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins

 

The ECG shown in the image is indicative of ventricular tachycardia . Pulseless VT is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate defibrillation. The appropriate treatment for VT during CPR is to deliver an unsynchronized shock (defibrillation) at an initial dose of 2 J/kg. After delivering the shock, it is crucial to immediately resume CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing the rhythm and pulse, as this maximizes the chances of successful resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse: This option is incorrect because checking the pulse immediately after delivering the shock wastes valuable time. The correct protocol is to immediately resume CPR after the shock, without pausing to check the pulse, as this enhances the likelihood of restoring circulation.

 

Option C. Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is used for treating certain types of arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or atrial fibrillation (AF), but it is not appropriate for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. In pulseless VT , unsynchronized defibrillation is required.

 

Option D. Continue CPR till pulse is back: This option is partially correct but incomplete. While continuing CPR is essential, the most crucial intervention in the case of pulseless VT is defibrillation. Without delivering a shock, the chances of survival are significantly diminished.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pediatric cardiac arrest with pulseless ventricular tachycardia on the ECG, the correct immediate action is to defibrillate with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing.

questions.text: A child presented with intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow biopsy showed a “crumpled paper appearance.” What is your best diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glucocerebrosidase

 

The Ans. is Glucocerebrosidase, which is associated with Gaucher disease. Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside within macrophages, resulting in cells that have a characteristic "crumpled paper" appearance when viewed under a microscope. The presence of these cells, along with symptoms like intellectual disability and hepatosplenomegaly, strongly suggests Gaucher disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GALT enzyme: This enzyme is related to Galactosemia, a disorder of galactose metabolism. It does not present with a "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow biopsies, nor is it associated with the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease is a glycogen storage disorder due to a deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase. It typically involves muscle weakness and cardiomegaly but does not produce the "crumpled paper" cells seen in bone marrow biopsies.

 

Option D. Niemann-Pick disease: This is another lysosomal storage disorder, but it is due to sphingomyelinase deficiency. The characteristic cells in Niemann-Pick disease have a "foamy" appearance, not the "crumpled paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "crumpled paper appearance" in bone marrow cells is a hallmark of Gaucher disease, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

questions.text: A 58-year-old individual presents to the emergency department with symptoms of high fever, chills, and a cough producing greenish sputum. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg, pulse rate of 108 bpm, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. The patient's chest X-ray is displayed below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Community-acquired pneumonia

 

This patient's presentation with acute symptoms including high fever, chills, and a productive cough with greenish sputum is indicative of an infectious process. The chest X-ray showing lobar consolidation without evidence of nodules or significant lymphadenopathy supports the diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). This diagnosis is further corroborated by the patient's vital signs showing mild tachycardia, elevated respiratory rate, and decreased oxygen saturation, which are typical in cases of pneumonia due to the body's response to pulmonary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubercular pleural effusion: Tubercular pleural effusion typically presents with chronic symptoms like weight loss and night sweats, and the chest X-ray would show pleural effusion characterized by fluid accumulation, which is not evident in this case.

 

Option C. Coal worker pneumoconiosis: Coal worker pneumoconiosis would feature a history of prolonged coal dust exposure and the X-ray would show small opacities primarily in the upper lobes, which do not correspond with the findings in the given image.

 

Option D. Silicosis: Silicosis would also present with a history of silica exposure, typically in occupational settings like mining or sandblasting, and the X-ray would show nodular opacities predominantly in the upper lobes. Additionally, "eggshell" calcification of lymph nodes might be seen, which is absent here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Community-acquired pneumonia is present with acute onset symptoms such as fever, productive cough, and chills, along with radiographic evidence showing lobar consolidation or interstitial infiltrates, and it requires prompt antibiotic treatment based on culture results to manage the infection effectively.

questions.text: A man presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident with complaints of chest pain and difficulty breathing. An X-ray was taken and is displayed below. Based on the findings, which type of breathing pattern is most likely observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paradoxical respiration

 

Paradoxical respiration is typically observed in patients with flail chest, a condition arising from blunt trauma resulting in three or more contiguous rib fractures in at least two places per rib. This type of injury leads to a segment of the chest wall moving independently of the rest of the thoracic cage. During inspiration, this segment moves inward rather than outward, which is abnormal and is termed paradoxical respiration. This can significantly impair respiratory function, leading to symptoms like those reported by the patient: chest pain and breathing difficulty.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Cheyne-Stokes respiration: Cheyne-Stokes respiration, characterized by rhythmic waxing and waning of breathing with periods of apnea, is often seen in neurological diseases or in cases of severe heart failure, not typically associated with trauma.

 

Option C. Biot’s respiration: Biot’s respiration, consisting of irregular periods of apnea interspersed with regular deep breaths, is commonly associated with increased intracranial pressure or brain injury, not directly linked to rib fractures.

 

Option D. Kussmaul respiration: Kussmaul respiration, marked by deep and labored breathing, is commonly seen in metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, not trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical respiration is a key clinical indicator of flail chest, resulting from severe chest trauma with multiple rib fractures causing a segment of the chest wall to move independently. This condition presents significant management challenges, necessitating interventions like oxygen administration, pain management, and potentially more aggressive respiratory support.

questions.text: A male patient presents with a history of urinary tract infection (UTI), suspected to be caused by bacterial infection. Which of the following structures is utilized by bacteria for adherence to the urinary tract?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae, also known as pili, are hair-like appendages that extend from the cell surface of bacteria. These structures are essential for the adherence of bacteria to host cells, facilitating the colonization of host tissues which is crucial in the development of infections such as UTIs. Fimbriae enable bacteria to attach to the epithelial cells of the urinary tract, overcoming the flushing action of urine which would otherwise help clear bacteria from the urinary tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: The cytoplasmic membrane is a fundamental component of all cells, including bacteria. It functions as a selective barrier for the entry and exit of substances and is not directly involved in the adherence to host tissues.

 

Option B. Cilia: Cilia are primarily found in eukaryotic cells, such as those in the human respiratory tract and certain protozoa. They are used for locomotion or to move substances over cell surfaces, such as mucus in the respiratory tract, and are not a bacterial structure used for adherence.

 

Option D. Flagella: Flagella are long, whip-like structures used by bacteria primarily for motility rather than for adherence. They enable bacteria to move towards favorable environments but do not play a direct role in the attachment to host tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are used for adherence to host cells, particularly in the context of urinary tract infections. Their presence allows bacteria to establish infection by resisting the natural defense mechanisms of the host, such as urine flow in the urinary tract.

choices.text: Increased membrane potential of the oocyte
Decreased membrane potential of the oocyte

questions.text: What mechanism occurs within the zona pellucida of an oocyte to prevent the entry of multiple sperm cells after the initial fertilization?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cortical reaction

 

The cortical reaction is critical to prevent polyspermy, which is the fertilization of an oocyte by more than one sperm. This reaction happens after the first sperm has successfully fertilized the oocyte. Enzymes from cortical granules in the oocyte are released into the space between the oocyte plasma membrane and the zona pellucida. These enzymes then modify the zona pellucida by breaking down ZP3 receptors, making it impermeable to additional sperm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acrosomal reaction: The acrosomal reaction is the process by which the sperm's acrosome releases digestive enzymes to penetrate the zona pellucida and reach the oocyte. While necessary for the initial penetration, it does not prevent subsequent sperm from entering.

 

Option B. Increased membrane potential of the oocyte and D. Decreased membrane potential of the oocyte: Changes in the membrane potential of the oocyte, whether an increase or decrease, occur as a response to sperm contact and help in triggering the cortical reaction but are not the primary mechanism for preventing polyspermy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cortical reaction is essential, as it is the primary defense against polyspermy, ensuring that only one sperm fertilizes the oocyte, thereby maintaining the correct genetic composition of the embryo.

choices.text: Biofilm increases susceptibility to antibiotics
Biofilm offers resistance, necessitating removal of the catheter
Biofilm does not affect antibiotic susceptibility
Biofilm can be washed off from the catheter

questions.text: A patient with a long-term central intravenous line, currently on antibiotics, develops a fever. Blood cultures indicate the presence of Staphylococcus epidermidis and biofilm formation on the catheter. What is the significance of the biofilm in terms of antibiotic resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biofilm offers resistance, necessitating removal of the catheter

 

Biofilms consist of microcolonies of bacteria encapsulated within a self-produced glycocalyx matrix that adheres to surfaces, including medical devices like catheters. This matrix acts as a barrier against antibiotic penetration and shields the bacteria from the host's immune response, significantly reducing the effectiveness of antimicrobial treatments. Due to this protective barrier, bacteria within biofilms are often less metabolically active and can become dormant, making them harder to eradicate with standard antibiotic therapies. As a result, when biofilms are present on indwelling medical devices such as catheters, the recommended course of action is often to remove the device to effectively manage the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biofilm increases susceptibility to antibiotics: Incorrect, as biofilms actually decrease the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics, not increase it.

 

Option C. Biofilm does not affect antibiotic susceptibility: Incorrect, as biofilms significantly affect antibiotic susceptibility by providing a protective barrier against them.

 

Option D. Biofilm can be washed off from the catheter: Incorrect, biofilms are notoriously difficult to remove through simple washing or flushing. Established biofilms typically require more aggressive interventions, such as mechanical debridement or the use of specialized chemical agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biofilms confer significant antibiotic resistance to bacteria colonizing indwelling medical devices. The standard response when biofilms are suspected involves the removal of the device to prevent further complications and to manage the infection effectively.

choices.text: 1 - Liver, 2 - Spleen, 3 - Ovary, 4 - Testis
1 - Brain, 2 - Tonsils, 3 - BMI, 4 - Genital Organs
1 - Brain, 2 - Somatic growth, 3 - Ovary, 4 - Height
1 - Brain, 2 - Waldeyer's ring, 3 - Somatic growth, 4 - Testicular growth

questions.text: What biological growth patterns are represented by each curve in the following graph, tracking development from birth to 20 years?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 - Brain, 2 - Waldeyer's ring, 3 - Somatic growth, 4 - Testicular growth

 

  • Curve 1: Represents brain growth, which rapidly progresses to reach approximately 90% of its adult size by age 2, indicating early and rapid neural development.
  • Curve 2: Corresponds to the growth of Waldeyer's ring, which includes the tonsils and other lymphatic tissues in the throat. This area sees a peak in growth around 4 to 8 years and typically regresses afterward.
  • Curve 3: Depicts somatic (bodily) growth, which follows a sigmoid curve, showing initial rapid growth in early years and another spurt during puberty.
  • Curve 4: Illustrates testicular growth, which remains dormant until puberty when significant growth occurs, marking sexual maturation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The distinct growth patterns for specific organs and tissues: Brain growth is rapid and completes early by age 2, Waldeyer's ring (including tonsils) peaks between ages 4 and 8, somatic growth follows a sigmoid pattern with a puberty spike, and testicular growth begins its significant increase at puberty.

choices.text: A - Auriculotemporal nerve; B - Greater auricular nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve
A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Auriculotemporal nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve
A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Facial and Vagus nerve; C - Auriculotemporal nerve
A - Facial and Vagus nerve; B - Greater auricular nerve; C - Auriculotemporal nerve

questions.text: Match the nerve supply to the respective regions of the external ear as shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Greater auricular nerve; B - Auriculotemporal nerve; C - Facial and Vagus nerve

 

The nerve supply of the external ear, particularly the pinna, is complex and involves multiple nerves:

 

  • Greater auricular nerve (A) primarily supplies the majority of the medial surface and the posterior part of the lateral surface of the pinna.
  • Auriculotemporal nerve (B) is responsible for innervating the tragal area and the crus of the helix.
  • Facial and Vagus nerves (C), where the auricular branch of the Vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve) and the Facial nerve, supply the concha and adjacent regions on the medial surface. The Facial nerve also contributes to the innervation of the area around the retroauricular groove.

 

This innervation is critical for the sensory perception and vasomotor control of the ear, influencing both physiological and reflexive responses of the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nerve supply of Pinna

questions.text: Based on the constituents shown on the IV fluid bag, identify the fluid typically given to post-operative patients.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ringer lactate

 

Ringer lactate, also known as Hartmann's solution, is the correct answer as it is a balanced crystalloid solution commonly used in medical settings, especially post-operatively. The constituents listed in the question include sodium 131 mEq, chloride 112 mEq, potassium 5 mEq, bicarbonate (as lactate) 29 mEq, and calcium 2 mEq, aligning perfectly with Ringer lactate's typical composition. This solution does not contain glucose, which is consistent with the description provided. Ringer lactate is beneficial for:

 

  • Correcting severe hypovolemia
  • Treating metabolic acidosis
  • Managing fluid requirements post-surgery, in burn patients, or during diarrhea
  • Correcting hypokalemia and diabetic ketoacidosis It is not recommended in cases like severe shock, liver disease, or when blood transfusions are given because the calcium content can react with citrate in stored blood and lead to clot formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Haemaccel: Haemaccel is a colloid used mainly for rapid volume replacement in circulatory shock, burns, and trauma. It contains different concentrations of sodium, calcium, and potassium. Haemaccel can release histamine, potentially requiring antihistamine support, and is used in heart-lung machine operations, making it less suitable for routine post-operative hydration.

 

Option C. Isolyte P: Isolyte P is a pediatric crystalloid solution enriched with glucose and various electrolytes. It is specifically formulated for children and involves specific contraindications such as hyponatremia and renal failure, making it inappropriate for general post-operative adult use.

 

Option D. Isolyte M: Isolyte M is designed for maintenance fluid therapy, containing glucose and several electrolytes tailored for ongoing care rather than immediate post-operative needs. It addresses long-term balance issues such as hypokalemia in patients with intact renal function and is not suitable for acute post-operative management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For post-operative care, Ringer lactate is the preferred IV fluid due to its balanced electrolyte composition that mimics the body's plasma, making it ideal for managing fluid and electrolyte balance after surgery.

choices.text: Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin.
It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage.
Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease.
Metronidazole is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female complains of fever, headache, and vomiting for the past 3 days. She has been residing at an army recruitment camp for the last three weeks. During an examination, she displays neck stiffness and a maculopapular rash over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following statements is false about the disease she is likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metronidazole is the drug of choice.

 

The patient's symptoms and living conditions suggest she may be suffering from meningococcal meningitis, which is caused by Neisseria meningitidis. This bacteria is a Gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive diplococcus known for causing outbreaks in communal living settings like military camps.

 

  • Option D is false because Metronidazole is not the drug of choice for treating meningococcal meningitis. The appropriate treatment would be a third-generation cephalosporin such as ceftriaxone. Chloramphenicol can be used in cases where the patient has a penicillin allergy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carriers of this disease can be treated with Rifampicin: True. Carriers of meningococcal disease can indeed be treated with Rifampicin, which is effective in eradicating nasopharyngeal carriage of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Option B. It can lead to adrenal hemorrhage: True. One of the severe complications of meningococcal sepsis is bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome, which can be a life-threatening complication.

 

Option C. Terminal complement deficiency increases the risk of this disease: True. Individuals with terminal complement deficiencies are at increased risk for meningococcal infections. This is because complement plays a critical role in opsonization and killing of the bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningococcal meningitis should be treated with a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone, not Metronidazole, which is not effective against Neisseria meningitidis. Awareness of correct treatment options is crucial for effective management and improved outcomes in patients suspected of having meningococcal meningitis.

questions.text: A CT scan of a patient with a hydatid cyst is shown below. What is the type of hydatid cyst as per the Gharbi classification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type 2

 

Hydatid cyst is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species (dog tapeworm). Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus, while sheep are the usual intermediate hosts. Humans, however, are accidental intermediate hosts and considered end-stage hosts, as there is no human-to-human transmission.

 

The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is typically asymptomatic until complications occur. The most common symptoms include:

 

  • Abdominal pain
  • Dyspepsia
  • Vomiting The most common physical finding is hepatomegaly.

 

Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are often solitary.

 

Diagnosis: CT scan is the best imaging modality for diagnosing hydatid cysts, showing a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline and septations. The diagnosis is supported by the presence of a multiloculated cyst on ultrasound, with floating membranes within the cyst as seen on a CT scan.

 

Signs of Cyst Disruption:

 

  • Water Lily Sign/ Camalote Sign: Air-fluid level with a floating membrane.
  • Rising Sun Sign/ Serpent Sign: A double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at the bottom.
  • Empty Cyst Sign: When all the contents of the cyst are removed.

 

Imaging Findings:

 

  • The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations with a rosette or honeycomb appearance.
  • Serpent Sign: Wavy membranes within the cyst seen on CT imaging.
  • Ball of Wool Sign: When the contents of the cyst settle in the dependent portion on ultrasound.
  • Water Lily Sign: When there is detachment of the endocyst membrane, resulting in floating membranes within the pericyst, mimicking the appearance of a water lily on ultrasound.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Type 1: Typically seen as a unilocular cystic lesion with a double-line sign (CE1).
  • Type 3: Associated with cysts having daughter cysts in a solid matrix (CE3b).
  • Type 4: Contains heterogeneous, hypo or hyper-echoic content, with no daughter cysts (CE4).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Water Lily" sign is seen in Type 2 hydatid cysts as per the Gharbi classification, caused by detachment of the endocyst membrane, leading to floating membranes within the cyst.
